number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												Deponia aims to be quirky to sets itself apart from many of its kind. It has however fail in many different aspects:1. Characters: In a story-driven game such as this, the characters are far from memorable. Each one seems to try its upmost effort to sound sarcastic, cynical or downright idiotic to an extent that it fails to deliver an exciting blend of characters. Don’t get me wrong, I love characters that make a fool of themselves (e.g. Rincewind from Discworld) but what Rufus tried to portray feels way too forced. Instead of the light, bite-sized comedy pieces that I was expecting, I witnessed sloppy production and narrations. Granted, there were some funny moments, but it is difficult to give proper credit given the rarity of such occasion.2. Puzzle: Again, another essential element to a point-and-click game. This is the major flaw of the game. I give huge leeway to such games where logic and questionable detours need to be taken or when pesky puzzle elements are involved that somehow blocks the progress of the game simply to discover that it makes little sense. Deponia is King of this behaviour right here.3. Artwork: Despite the fact that I am not a fan of this kind of artwork, I must say this is where Deponia shines the most, the artwork of its kind is downright stunning, exuding a very unique feel towards the world of Deponia.4. Music: Passable music, though there are some memorable ones. This, together with artwork, ensures a great thematic feel of its kind.Problems: As of 11th May 2013 a bug exists in the middle of the game where you will be stuck and unable to continue. I find this very mind-boggling that such a bug could have existed until now. This needs immediate repair.Overall, if you're a fan of point and click game, this game might be worth it, otherwise, stay clear away.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Deponia is the 1st part of a Trilogy that takes you to the junkyard world of Deponia where the stubborn, egocentric and yet bold boy Rufus dreams of leaving the tedious Deponia for the paradise Elysium seen floating in the sky above. For me the games biggest strength have to be it´s quite humorous tone which is especially notable in the often hillarious dialogues filled with sarcasm. It should be noted that the main protagonist Rufus is not a very likeable character, he´s actually an excellent example of the 'anti-hero', which might put some people of but I myself found it refereshing to play as a flawed character instead of the usual Paragon.The graphics and especially the backgrounds are really nice and the character models are not far behind. The Audio is excellent and especially the Bard theme during some of the cutscenes. The puzzles are varied in difficulty which I like but all those who where tougher to crack had some form hints often found in dialouges with characters nearby. The puzzles also have a 'skip' option for those who find them annoying and want to get on with the story which is nice I guess.One final notice is that the 'silly mode' called Droggeljug which is needed in order to get the final achievement for 100 % is super annoying and I would actually go against my usual view and recommend to 'cheat' in order to get it. Having to play another full playtrough with no dialouges in a game based on dialogue was not a very bright idea by Daedalic in my opinion but it´s a minor flaw in a otherwise great game.I fully recommend buying this although the full price of 19,99 € might be a tad to much considering the lack of replayability but at a -50 % or better discount it´s definatly a good buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												Deponia aims to be quirky to sets itself apart from many of its kind. It has however fail in many different aspects:1. Characters: In a story-driven game such as this, the characters are far from memorable. Each one seems to try its upmost effort to sound sarcastic, cynical or downright idiotic to an extent that it fails to deliver an exciting blend of characters. Don’t get me wrong, I love characters that make a fool of themselves (e.g. Rincewind from Discworld) but what Rufus tried to portray feels way too forced. Instead of the light, bite-sized comedy pieces that I was expecting, I witnessed sloppy production and narrations. Granted, there were some funny moments, but it is difficult to give proper credit given the rarity of such occasion.2. Puzzle: Again, another essential element to a point-and-click game. This is the major flaw of the game. I give huge leeway to such games where logic and questionable detours need to be taken or when pesky puzzle elements are involved that somehow blocks the progress of the game simply to discover that it makes little sense. Deponia is King of this behaviour right here.3. Artwork: Despite the fact that I am not a fan of this kind of artwork, I must say this is where Deponia shines the most, the artwork of its kind is downright stunning, exuding a very unique feel towards the world of Deponia.4. Music: Passable music, though there are some memorable ones. This, together with artwork, ensures a great thematic feel of its kind.Problems: As of 11th May 2013 a bug exists in the middle of the game where you will be stuck and unable to continue. I find this very mind-boggling that such a bug could have existed until now. This needs immediate repair.Overall, if you're a fan of point and click game, this game might be worth it, otherwise, stay clear away.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Deponia is a purebred point-and-click adventure that follows the misadventures of Rufus, a dreamer, an inventor, a visionary - and a jerk. And make no mistake, he's not a misunderstood scoundrel who does his best but always seems to end up on the wrong side of the right thing. He's selfish, egomaniacal and a legitimate, all-around♥♥♥♥♥♥ He has no qualms at all about putting the screws to his best friend, and considers his long-suffering girlfriend's insistence that he get a job and do the dishes once in awhile to be utterly unreasonable. His only goal in life is to escape his dirty, dreary life and make his way to the distant realm of Elysium, a land of milk and honey that floats high in the sky above his home.The opening segment of Deponia is dedicated to Rufus' latest scheme to reach Elysium, and while the outcome is all too predictable, I laughed like a fool at the payoff anyway. It's not what you'd call sophisticated humor - think Wile E. Coyote meets Homer Simpson and you'll have a pretty good idea of how it plays out - but the presentation is so well done that it works anyway.Unfortunately, after getting off to a strong start, Deponia sags rather dramatically in the second half of the lengthy opening chapter, when the oddly-named and inconveniently-cybernetic Goal is introduced to the action. She's a beautiful Elysian female who may well be Rufus' ticket to the good life, but before any of that can happen he must first revive her and then prove his "claim" to her with the town's mayor. It lacks direction and is weighed down with frustratingly obtuse puzzles, and although I may not be the sharpest cookie I have no idea how some of these puzzles could be solved without a walkthrough. It drags narratively too, as the priority shifts from sharp storytelling to confounding players with an overload of tough brainteasers. The story thankfully picks up again in the second and third chapters, which pass much more enjoyably with better pacing and far more reasonable puzzles.The game suffers from a few technical issues, most of which relate to the translation from the game's original German. There are occasional spots of odd or awkward terminology, one line of subtitled text appears in German rather than English and the subtitles don't appear at all in a multiple choice puzzle in the second chapter, forcing you to either guess your way through it or, again, rely on a walkthrough. It doesn't do much to fill out its fiction, either. The role of the Organon, a sort of half-robotic military organization-slash-secret police that seems to serve the people of Elyisum, is never clearly explained, nor is the exact nature of Goal's brain implant, which is really just a cheap way to bring her in and out of the action as needed. But in spite of those missteps, Deponia is a success. It brings absolutely nothing new to the genre, but it's legitimately funny, brilliantly produced and, aside from some slogging in the middle, moves quickly and smoothly from start to finish. It's not quite great, but it's awfully good.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Deponia is the 1st part of a Trilogy that takes you to the junkyard world of Deponia where the stubborn, egocentric and yet bold boy Rufus dreams of leaving the tedious Deponia for the paradise Elysium seen floating in the sky above. For me the games biggest strength have to be it´s quite humorous tone which is especially notable in the often hillarious dialogues filled with sarcasm. It should be noted that the main protagonist Rufus is not a very likeable character, he´s actually an excellent example of the 'anti-hero', which might put some people of but I myself found it refereshing to play as a flawed character instead of the usual Paragon.The graphics and especially the backgrounds are really nice and the character models are not far behind. The Audio is excellent and especially the Bard theme during some of the cutscenes. The puzzles are varied in difficulty which I like but all those who where tougher to crack had some form hints often found in dialouges with characters nearby. The puzzles also have a 'skip' option for those who find them annoying and want to get on with the story which is nice I guess.One final notice is that the 'silly mode' called Droggeljug which is needed in order to get the final achievement for 100 % is super annoying and I would actually go against my usual view and recommend to 'cheat' in order to get it. Having to play another full playtrough with no dialouges in a game based on dialogue was not a very bright idea by Daedalic in my opinion but it´s a minor flaw in a otherwise great game.I fully recommend buying this although the full price of 19,99 € might be a tad to much considering the lack of replayability but at a -50 % or better discount it´s definatly a good buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Overall, I found the trilogy enjoyable. I loved all the art in this. The backgrounds were very interesting, detailed, and beutifully portrayed a wide variety of the many towns cities landscapes, and other areas of this trash-heap of a planet. The character designs had this simplistic "kiddy" style that I found particularyly appealing. I think that the characters designs were pretty effective in expressing each characer wtih a huge variety of characters of many shapes, sizes, and postures. The art of the game, while playing, overall reminded me of pajamasam, being a point-and-click adventure with upbeat, "kiddy" looking characters in combination with a vast world of many areas drasticly differeing from one another in tone and atmosphere. Now with gamplay, well... Puzzles in this game, thinking back now, where ususally ridiculously hard to solve. I was stuck several times only to look at a walkthrough only to find that the answer makes me think "how in the world was I supposed to figure THAT out." Without the walkthrough I porbably would not have finished the game. I already spent like a good hour sitting there trying to think of answers. I did NOT have the patience of trying EVERYTHING on EVERYTHING so it was either use my own logic to its most abstract limits or the walkthrough. There were sometimes were I was on a roll in solving puzzels and that was pretty satisfying. The voice acting was pretty decent. It sure beats Dream. My friend told me he quickly got tired of Rufus' voice but I wasn't too bothered. I was pretty invested in the story. The story was the otherthing besides the art that kept me playing. It has some cool twists and reveals that suprised me. Aand I think the ending of the trilogy beats Mass Efect's.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												I bought this when it was 95% off just intending to sell the cards. Fortunately I had just bought an amazing game that kept my attention for way longer than I was expecting. Deponia has a simple history and goal: you are Rufus, you hate your planet and wants to leave it. That's it. However, don't think that leaving your literaly trash planet will be simple. You will have to think, explore, realize things and be creative. You will find yourself in situations like "WTF DO I DO WITH AN UNCONSCIOUS PARROT, A LAUGH GAS BALLOON, A DENTIST DRILLING MACHINE AND THIS DEVICE THAT CHANGES THE MAGNETIC FIELD OF THE PLANET??" that will drive you crazy and curious. Deponia is the only Point-and-click game that is funny instead of annoying that I have ever played. I do recommend.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												I am huge fan of Monkey Island, and this is the first game I've found that comes close. It has good humour, nice exploration and beautiful illustrative artwork (think MI3). Downsides are that you're launched straight into a tutorial, rather than given time to watch the scene be set; in addition, the voice recordings aren't great in that a) the artists haven't received full direction, so sometimes they stress the wrong word and ruin the joke, and b) there isn't enough variety in responses. The game is also fairly short but is actually a lot longer than most, and definitely longer than your average Indie game. In all, really, really good. Enough to make me buy the sequel :)

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Top notch characters, artworks, and musics. If you want to relive the old Lucasarts games atmosphere this is the game for you. (note: only the first chapter, reasons in the edit)EDIT: Just finished the first 3 chapters (the 4th has just been released). I still recommend Deponia, but I can't compare it to Lucasarts games anymore, there's some racism/sexism/and just some plain bad ideas that has been put into the second and third games. I think the creator's idea was to make the character ignorantly racists, sexists, and a bad person overall, but I think it would have been better to just leave Rufus as it was in the first game, a goofy clumsy hatcher of bad plans. Nonetheless, this haven't changed completely how I feel about this game's characters and artworks. It's still a great game.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												You play the part of "Rufus", a quirky odd fella' from the village Kuvaq", on the trash and scrap-covered world of "Deponia" - Think: Junkyard with housing opportunities!This Point & Click adventure is full of funny, clever, and sometimes very tricky puzzles to solve. It goes to redicilous lenghts at times, so there might be a couple of self-loathing moments where you look up a guide, and then *facepalm yourself, due to the obvious ( in the world of Deponia) solution. But don't worry, the pace of the game is great, and you wont find yourself stuck to often.It tells it's story with a humongous portion of humour. You will surely smile and stay curious throughout the game.The voiceacting is also very good - where every character seems to have been properly worked on.- If you like Point & Click games with a twist of comedy. This is for you!

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												A decent entry in the point-and-click genre. I'd recommend getting Deponia on sale, though, considering the amount of gameplay. I consider the replayability to be a bit low, considering there are not multiple possibilities and you've already figured out the puzzles. A few pros and cons: + I thought that the story behind the world of Deponia was fairly interesting. + Rufus grew on me by the end, despite his obvious flaws.+ Good style and gameplay.- A lot of the puzzles were counter-intuitive to me, and I did reference a walkthrough quite a bit while playing.- No well-developed female characters.- A bug with the inventory button disappearing forced me to play with a mouse instead of just my trackpad.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												   This is the first part, out of a 3 part adventure story, where the main character is Rufus, a pathologically egotistical individual, that wants to escape from a planet that is now all filled with junk. I found out that middle click would highlight all the objects that you can interact with, close to the end of the game but I didn't had any real problems finding objects as the art style is pretty well done. The game has humor everywhere and unless you really get stuck, it's a really fun experience. I don't normally play adventures, so when I say that I didn't use any walkthroughs, it means that the game is not that difficult and things are generally intuitive enough. There are also a few fun puzzles thrown in there that you can skip if you want.Rating: I, me, and mine!*Editors'Choice*http://pixelloot.com

												Review for the whole saga.First of all, I don't really like point-and-click games, but for some reasons... I loved Deponia saga. Pros:Puzzles: In a lot of point-and-click you have to figure it out on your own, without hints, and so you should try to combine random items\click everywhere\etc... In Deponia you'll get tons of hints, in dialogues\descriptions\etc... you'll always find great hints.Awesome graphics Awesome musics Awesome voice acting Nice storyFUNNY ! Dialogues\puzzles\descriptions\even trying to use the wrong item, will make you laugh. The whole saga takes ~30h, it's never repetitive Platypuses RufusGreat inventory system Cons:Last chapter (Goodbye Deponia) it's a bit buggyI don't want to spoil so I'll just say that I'm REALLY REALLY REALLY disappointed with the ending...

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												I LOVE THIS GAME!!!!!This has to be the funniest point and click I have played in ages. Not only is it hillarious from start to finish. It is also incredibly challenging. You really have to think outside the box for some of these, but at the same time it makes sense, just like in Sam and Max. So you will find yourself explaining your reasoning for solving a puzzle to someone who doesn't play this, to only get a facial expression thrown back at you that says "What on earth are you on??" Lol. The mechanics are very old school, which is great, and definately hark back to the early DOS days. Being able to bring the items menu up and down via the mouse wheel is pure genius, and gives me a great sense of pleasure every time I do it.The visuals are gorgeous. Every landscape and character you see is very sharp and clean, with loads of colour and detail. The script, storyline, characters, songs, music and voice acting is phenomenal! The humour is very adult so I'd steer younger kids away from this (It's not Deadpool or anything but there's the odd bit of language and double entendre and it can get a little dark in places). This game had me hooked from start to finish. Even though I had to break away from and come back to it occasionally when I got stuck. Getting stuck was definately the most frustrating thing about this game, because you'd get a real head scratcher, not be able to solve it for a while, but really want to know what happens in the story. Still I don't think I would change anything about this game. Amazing. Would definately recommend it and am looking forward to playing the next installment 'Chaos on Deponia'.

												This game shows the usual quality that is expected from Daedalic: Great production values for an adventure game, especially in terms of the animation. It’s also quite a novelty to play as an absolutely horrible person, and it’s interesting how that concept is integrated into the puzzles.But still I think it was a missed opportunity, since the game suffers from many pacing issues and illogical puzzles. There are many parts where the objectives aren’t evident, when at the same time there are many screens and objects to interact. Also, there’s many puzzles that even after checking the walkthrough I’m still scratching my head, which is a big no no in this genre. Newcomers are advised to check The Whispered World instead.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2013
												Where to start?With a lot of point and click adventure games, getting stuck is just part of the process and peeking at a walkthrough is fairly standard. The person making it is trying to be witty, creative, yet logical at the same time with the item combinations and just miss by a long shot. I’m fairly sure any point and click adventure fan has had this from time to time. There is always a moment or two you ask yourself… “Well, how was I seriously supposed to figure out that you had to put the chicken in the blender to get egg yolk, use that yolk with a daisy to make a cake, eat the cake and fart out the key to why I’m stuck.” My point being, the solutions aren’t always as obvious as they might think. I was very glad to find that Deponia isn’t like that. It’s consistently logically throughout the whole game. Admittedly, I did get stuck a few times, but it was more of a “how DIDN’T I get that?” rather than a “how did they think that made sense?”The Art style in Deponia is beautiful. A planet consisting of junk has never looked so good. The animation, music, voice acting and humour are all great to. There is a real charm about the characters and the little witty things that they say, that makes this game all that much more enjoyable. Which, talking of voice acting, reminds me… Droggeljug mode!I finished this game, looked back on the achievements I had left to get and I thought… …This is going to be interesting.Well, I never knew that Droggeljug mode would be as painful as it was. Finishing the game unlocks a new mode, where everything and anything that anyone says ever, comes out: “Droggeljug!”Now this is amusing all of a 10 second period, but after that it is quite painful. They say it in the same tone of voice every time. You may get the odd “Droggeljug?”, but apart from that it is fairly robotic. That being said it was still a funny little thing that they added which I thought was quite unique. I can imagine that this mode would make it a lot more challenging to play through if I didn’t literally just finish the game and still have everything fresh in my mind. Due to parts in the story where you need to note where the chat options are to get what you want off of them. (E.g. a character quiz’s you before they’ll give you a key, and all you have is a list of Droggeljugs for answers)It’s a challenging achievement, but a fun one. Despite that a lot of people probably muted it because the noise drove them crazy, I left it on low. Just to keep reminding me how ridiculous what I was doing really was.All in all, I love this game, it’s great. I can’t wait to start the next part in the story.TL;DR : Logical item combinations, engaging story, great humour, wonderful art and definitely a must have for any point and click adventure game lover.For anyone interested, My Review for Chaos on Deponia:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Stefneh/recommended/220740For anyone interested, My Review for Goodbye Deponia:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Stefneh/recommended/241910

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Point and click adventure game in my opinion stand on three pillars as a genre, narrative, game aesthetics and the puzzle complexity. If any of these pillars suffers it could entirely break the game and make a bland if not a terrible experience. This is what happened in Deponia with its narrative that just utterly failed the game's mostly good puzzle and aesthetic design. I just found that I was never engaged with the protagonist or the overall narrative which lead me to simply turn off the game on multiple occasions because I just got bored of the entire affair. The worst part was that even when I finally did finish the game I was given that utterly vapid void of an ending that brings closure to nothing and essentially demands that I play the next Deponia game to get a better picture of the narrative, which just isn't going to happen when I couldn't give a rats♥♥♥♥♥about anything going on to begin with.  I definitely saw the potential in Deponia and I saw the reasons people like it, but I can't in good conscious bring myself to anything other than warn people not to play this game. This is something that I hate to do to game's since I'm a big adherent to the philosophy that a game can be good regardless of how long it is, but for 19.99 a six hour experience just isn't good value for money for the player and that isn't acceptable in my opinion especially when its a mediocre experience at best.If you want to read a more detailed review you can find it over here on my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/07/deponia.html.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												So, the game is regularly on sale for 0,99€, which is a STEAL don't get me wrong. I suppose that's how most are going to be picking this up.But this game did not inspire me to play the rest of the series. Didn't enjoy it enough. The game is a classic point'n-click, with all the hallmarks of the genre. The humour, collecting things, rubbing things together to make new things, list-based dialogue trees and "quirky" characters. So If you have nostalgia for these sort of games, you may enjoy it more. But I grew up in a different era, and while I enjoyed some of the monkey island games for their kickass music, this game doesn't quite have the same sort of charm. It also brings along the thing that ruined my enjoyment of the game: the adventure game logic. I played this game with a guide open in another window, and I have some shame for that, but I spent maybe two hours of play time stuck on various puzzles, and that just isn't my idea of a good time. One unintuitive puzzle would be an anomily, but more than three is more like poor design. The Visual are, well, lopsided. from the stills and the promotional art, you might thing that the game looks pretty good. in action though, the animation is really basic, with a minimum number of frames used to convey movement, and a limited number of facial expressions. Voice acting is also decent overall, with few standout performances for better or for worse.  And the story.... well, the writing has some pretty good moments, but on the whole it still often fails to entertain. I will still give the game credit for the writing of Rufus, the MC. A lot of games try to go for a "scoundrel" type of main character, who's somehow a rebel who doesn't play by the rules, but also has a heart of gold, but here they bring the contradiction in that type of hero to it's logical conclusion: Because he acts like typical adventure game character, the other charcters see Rufus as a useless, kleptomaniac, harebrained and unpleasant person, while he sees himself as "too good" to live among them. I would say his defining character moment is when he has an arguement with his ex-girlfriend (who still houses and feeds him) to get the key to her first aid kit, from which he takes some tranquilizer which he uses to  come back, drug her and steal her stuff. Having Rufus be a real ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is what's important for him to have any real character developement. As for the side characters, some get laughs, and some get groans, and some are simple plot devices. Unfortunately, the latter category includes the series female lead, Goal (seriously?) who is the cornerstone of the plot for the whole game, yet doesn't say anything meaningful to make you invested in her. All in all, Deponia is only recommended to the fans of this particular genre, and especially hard puzzles. For the uninitiated, the game can be frustrating.

Posted: August 11, 2014
												Deponia is vaguely amusing. Forget comparisons to Terry Pratchett, Deponia is far more firmly based in the ground of a Piers Anthony novel. It excels in slapstick, crudity and vague jokes in reference to science and technology yet lacks the aplomb and depth that Pratchett conveys.As a game, it works well... the inventory system is effective, the navigation easy to grasp and the puzzles significantly *puzzling* with hints that are not overly obvious yet definitely helpful for someone paying attention. Graphically the game is most certainly comical, the character designs and environments well executed in terms of conveying character and atmosphere. However even on a system that exceeds specifications I did occasionally experience a drop in frame rate that threw out the animated voice synchronisation which was slightly offputting.In terms of sound the games is interesting, each animation and area has it's own unique sound, and the music is again... amusing and in keeping with the satirical elements of the game.However Deponia amused me, it did not quite captivate me as I hoped it would. I enjoyed the puzzles, and the graphics but the story simply failed to grab me. Perhaps this is slightly due to the characterization of Rufus. As much as he is meant to be an egotistical, narcissist incapable of helping others, it's not exactly an engaging sort of character to play. He ended up annoying me rather than maintaining my interest. As for Goal, the "heroine" she lies docile and helpless most of the time, the old archetype of the damsel in distress, so I couldn't even engage with desire to help her... who wants to save a lifeless body in a white jumpsuit... because that's pretty much Goal's character for most of the game?? (or perhaps that's just the feminist critic speaking)Plotline and characterization issues aside... Deponia does still manage to be fun to play, mainly because of the excellent level designs and puzzles.So I still recommend it as a fun game to play.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												Deponia features the mechanics of a classic point-and-click with a beautiful hand drawn graphics and an interesting (if a little short) soundtrack. In typical P&C fashion you explorer various environments, interacting with set pieces and collecting items to be used later, completing various tasks that range from the mundane to the ludicrous. The first act dragged on a little and had some real out-of-the-box puzzle solutions but the last two acts really pickup and are paced a little better.The artwork really is gorgeous and does an excellent job of bringing a world full of junk and debris to life. The soundtrack is pretty good but isn't what you would call easy listening so after hearing the same few songs over and over again in each act it can be a little grating. The writing was typically funny and the voice acting is top notch although at times the main character is a little overbearing.Overall Deponia is good fun (although maybe a little overpriced for the length when not on sale) and if you're a point and click fan it will be right up your alley. Be warned, if you're following the plot at all you're going want the rest of the series, cliffhanger city central.

Posted: July 13, 2015
'Deponia' is a humorous point and click adventure, which is near to 'The Books of Unwritten Tales' where you can feel the world and want to be part of it. *Hussa!*Desc:You play as 'Rufus' who is a egomaniac, prides himself on being the best and who wants to leave his scrap home planet Deponia to Elysium with a vengeance. On his mission he meets 'Goal' the love of his life. He is willing to do everything for her to win her heart AND to get to Elysium.Pros:+ Really nice painted graphics and animations+ Strong audio speakers+ Funny as hell (sometimes very rude humor)+ Tutorial is available+ Skippable mini-games + References to previous Daedalic games+ Demo available(+ Sequels for continuing fun)(+ Achievements [easy to collect] )Cons:- Annoying Droggeljug achievement (no shortcut)Recommended, even if it's not on sale, because of the great story and the awesome trappings playing on a planet/world full of scrap.9/10

Posted: December 31, 2015
"Life's a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ when you look at it..." - Monty Python pretty much summed up what living on Deponia is like. So it's no wonder protagonist Rufus wants to escape the literal pile of trash. Too bad he's an obnoxious, egocentric idiot who can barely do anything right, other than perhaps make various things blow up in various faces...A not-entirely-likeable definitely-not-hero for a protagonist is a classic ingredient for adventure gold, and Daedalic followed other parts of time-honored recipes, too. Puzzles from trivial to head-scratchers (the way some of them don't really have good hints for them may be the game's one Achilles heel), a graphics style that fits the comedic tone of the game and is executed well, plus some nifty little tricks that make playing eassier (like quick-warping to sscreen exits).If you think you live in a dump and have it rough, you ain't seen nothing yet and totally need to treat yourself to the Deponia experience. Ideally, look for a package deal that includes the sequels - even though this is a full-length adventure, it's really rather open-ended.

Posted: April 29, 2014
												Deponia is a good little point and click adventure game. It has its share of tedious puzzles but most of them are good and makes sense (not a la Discworld). The story is good enough although very linear (we can argue a story is always linear :p ) in my opinion. We are far from games or stories such as the Longest Journey or Monkey Island.The recommended inventory system using the mouse wheel is extremely good and works very well, you can also hit the space bar at anytime to highlight every clickable objects in an area and the hand drawn graphics are really fantastic.I noticed a few bugs here and there, some of the clickable objects would eventually become non-clickable, and sometimes, the dialogue options are sometime off screen (probably not optimized for my resolution ?). The dialogues are well written and the actors did a great work in my opinion but the sound is not normalized very well making it sometime an inaudible mess.Finally, I want to mention that Rufus (the hero) goofiness only worked halfway for me. He is very one dimensional and his lines became very repetitive quickly. Some other characters such as Toni, Kuvac's mayor or Lotti are just more interesting making the world of Deponia a very believable one.If you can go through all the above, then yes, I think you will like Deponia.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												If you're looking at this game when it's going for 2$ get the damn game. If it's going for 20$ as usual... maybe only if you're really into point-and-click games, and have tried other ones. It's a solid enough buy nonetheless. (just my opinion)A fantastic game with a unique cast of characters and beautifully drawn sceneries. The story itself, beneath the cartoonish appearance, was actually quite intriguing and compelling at times, though admittedly hindered by tedious game pacing (a good example being spending easily 30+ minutes simply making a espresso.). Playing while reading a walkthrough is probably a good idea unless you intend to be in it for the long haul.The voice acting I particularly enjoyed; I did notice it did not always sync (particularly in the earlier parts of the game), something which bothered me- but it was nonetheless enjoyable to listen to the voiced dialogue anyways. Even for "supporting" characters I found the voice acting to be rather spot-on.Content-wise the game seemed rather sparse, but it was consistently enjoyable from beginning to end.

												Excellent, funny, point and click puzzle adventure.Great stylised graphics, good sound and voice, hilarious script. The humour fondly reminded me a little of the first Discworld game.Very simple and easy controls and game play, the silly intro teaches you all you need to know to get right into the story.Throughout, the characters and descriptions provide good (but not too obvious) clues to help you move forward and complete the various puzzles.Very well put together and nicely balanced. Posted: September 1, 2015
												I got this game on a hunch (& on a discount), because I'm a fan of  "Monkey Island", "Telltale"  and other point click adventures, and I wanted something new from this genre to explore.+ This game has a unique and quirky art and a flowy animation.+ The achievements are interesting and challenging to achieve, and I was able to get all of them (Droggeljug droggeljug droggeljug, droggeljug? Droggeljug!)+ The adventure lasted me about two or three days of gameplay.+/- The puzzles are doable and somewhat "easy" at first, but as the game progresses the puzzles do get more difficult and all around brain aching, though still enjoyable (most of the time).+/- The music is catchy but somewhat repetitive.+/- Conversations are not always helpful, but most always funny and add laughable moments and many, many references.+/- Locations vary, at some you stay for what feels like the longest time and there is a lot to explore, others are small and frustrating because there's not much to do in them and yet you get stuck in them in what feels like forever.+/- Characters are rather boring and go through NO development what so ever. Rufus stays stupid, Toni stays angry, Wenzel stays annoying &  Goal is just boobs on legs. Overall, I enjoyed this game and will recommend it to anyone who enjoys a good point click adventure, though not for the full price. It is not the best one out there, but it was a fun experience & I have played the whole trilogy.7\10

												Very enjoyable p&c game with good atmosphere and quite a lot of humour.You play a guy called Rufus trying to get off his boring literally trashy planet and go to the cool-people-place. On his way point&click and puzzles happen. The puzzles for progress are mostly solvable without the use of a guide, though I did have to look up a few things so I would not have to use every item in my inventory with every useable spot.All the achievements are gettable on first playthrough if you go full tryhard and read a guide all the time. If you're slightly less tryhard you may want to remember to save your game every once in a while so you don't have to go through entire chapters to get that one last thing you need. One achievement seemed only achievable through downloading a savefile (check forums), at least it wouldn't work for me the proper way and seemed a common problem.Definitely recommended, at least if purchased on sale, and I will play the other games in the series (when they go on sale).My one nuisance with this game was after doubleclicking to auto-go to next place, Rufus would take a few seconds to stroll slowly into the screen before I could doubleclick move to next place. Really annoying if you're not sure what you're supposed to do where and check every place because walkthroughs are for uncool people.Art, sound & voices all good, music is pretty cool, even Rufus thinks so as one of his idle moves is air-guitaring to the currently played music.

Posted: February 9, 2014
												When I was a kid I played Monkey Island and Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis so when I spotted this game on Steam and saw the fun, easy going attitude I simply couldn't resist it.You're playing the local celebrity(?) Rufus who's dreaming about reaching Elysium, the city in the sky and, being the genious you are there's nothing that's gonna stop you.The game got a nice sense of humor that I found very amusing and all the dialogues have voice actors who did a really nice job. In addition to the normal adventure clicker you also get to test your wits in some mini-puzzle games in order to progress (they're optional though so if you're not into that then there's a skip button although you won't get achievement for it).The controls were easy since they were just point and click, the mouse-pointer showing you the options available and the scroll-down inventory was a nice touch as well.As far as difficulty goes I'd say it's a little bit easier than the Monkey Island games while still hard enough to keep it interresting.Cons: Low replay value (since you already know where to go, what to do etc) and I also felt as if the game was a bit short compared to for example the Monkey Island games.Having trouble deciding weither to give it a 4 or a 3 due to the low replay value but I'm guessing that, based on the genre, nobody really expects that to be high anyway so... *drum roll*... 4 it is!1 - Crap, don't buy2 - Fun for an evening3 - It's an alright game4 - Great game5 - One of the best I've ever played

Posted: May 20, 2014
												The artistic style is visualy appealing, and the game itself is stable, but there are a lot of tedious elements to this game that don't quite add up. The puzzles aren't exactly connect the dots, more a combination of complete trial and error and hunt and peck. The story, although there, is brought to an almost complete hult by the puzzle mechanics in the game. Usually, a game like this tries to give you enough input that you still have challenging puzzles to figure out, but keeps things flowing enough that the story progresses in a fluent manner; not so much with Deponia. The game is bogged down by constant running around, back and forth, through the same areas, over and over again--which can get old rather quickly--and re-talking to the same people, time and time again, in order to get new items and information after every completed step, that it starts to bog down. Often times, the way that puzzles are put together (if you can even call most of them puzzles) gets old. Including how you are supposed to combine inventory items, and the silly things you are supposed to do in the environment to trigger actions. These elements get in the way of what could be a really great game. I enjoyed parts of Deponia, and detested others. A hate to give this game a 'no' recommendation, because of the clear presentation and easy interface, but unless you are a hardcore fan of point and click gaming that is more hunt and peck than puzzle based, and you have lots of time on your hands, this probably isn't the title for you. Certain puzzles make no logical sense and even seem hindering, especially when other solutions seem more readily available, but are completely unavailable. Puzzle and story should be singlular and lead into one another and Deponia is lacking in this respect. If the developer can improve on these elements in future releases then they will have an outstanding product!

Posted: December 24, 2015
												Deponia is a very challenging point-and-click game about a loaner trying to escape his junk-filled home planet. As a disclaimer I should say that I haven't finished this game and probably won't come back. The fact of the matter is, the game is just too difficult for me to finish. However, other than that, I actually really like what I've seen of the game, and I don't think a high difficulty alone should be enough to not recommend it. Just know that it's only for "hardcore" point-and-click players.Pros:+Decent humor that made me chuckle+Nice art, if you like the cartoony style+Even though it looks like a game for kids, it's actually targeting older players (hence the difficulty)+Lots of quirky characters and dialogue+Interesting storyMixed:+/-Difficulty wise, this is the Dark Souls of point-and-click games.Cons:-I had a bug where the game was too zoomed in and didn't fit the screen. Googling this revealed I could fix this by editing a config file, but occasionally the game would auto-edit the config file back and I would have to change it again. I was playing the Linux version of the game.In a way, I'm not qualified to write this review, since I haven't finished the game and therefore haven't seen the end of the story. I also can't speak for the length of the game, although I do already have 10 hours in it, and it feels like I'm not even halfway. Bottom line, I definitely like this game, but it's hard as balls, and you are going to end up tearing your hair out. It got so bad that I ended up trying to brute force solutions by making every single humanly possible combination of inventory items. But I'm sure there are people who are either better at this type of game than me or just like the challenge. For those people, this is the game for you.

Posted: July 15, 2015
												An adventure game that looks like a LucasArts one but, at least in terms of the puzzles, occasionally feels like a Sierra one. The story is pretty simple: A loser wants to escape his garbage dump of a home, and leave for someplace better.  The captions have some spelling errors, the voice acting occasionally falls flat, and the puzzles both halt the game's pacing, and sometimes serve to frustrate the player. Not many times, mind you, but there are a few that will make you ask, "Really?"So, why do I like the game? Well, I love adventure games, and Deponia is a nice throwback to the 90s halcyon days. Even the lead character, Rufus, feels like Guybrush Threepwood (Monkey Island). Actually, he feels more like a mix of Futurama's Fry and Bender, if that makes any sense.Of course, Deponia fans know what Rufus is really like: Herpes. Or, should I say, "a cooler version of herpes."The trilogy goes on sale fairly often, so I'd say wait for a deal and scoop up all three. Happy gaming!

Posted: September 30, 2015
												This is a cute point-and-click game with a Steampunk flavor.  Like a many p&c games though, the hunt for items to use on other items or locations can, by the end of the game, be more annoying than fun.  I do recommend the game though, as long as you're aware of a few things;There is dialogue.  A lot of it.  And while you can skip over it, kind of, it's not as easy to skip as in come other games.The main character walks slowly.  Seriously slowly.  I assume that was meant to be part of his laid-back character but, again, by the end of the game, it gets to be annoying.  There are cuts to different places that you can use but still, he needs to walk some places.  Slowly.I had a few technical issues. The Inventory link would disappear at random intervals and a couple times the program shut down, with no explanation as to why.  A reload always fixed it though.Ultimately, the game was fun and I enjoyed it, which is why I recommend it.  The story was engaging as well, so I'll definitely play the sequels.  All in all a nice, relaxing couple of hours.

Posted: May 4, 2015
												Very enjoyable p&c game with good atmosphere and quite a lot of humour.You play a guy called Rufus trying to get off his boring literally trashy planet and go to the cool-people-place. On his way point&click and puzzles happen. The puzzles for progress are mostly solvable without the use of a guide, though I did have to look up a few things so I would not have to use every item in my inventory with every useable spot.All the achievements are gettable on first playthrough if you go full tryhard and read a guide all the time. If you're slightly less tryhard you may want to remember to save your game every once in a while so you don't have to go through entire chapters to get that one last thing you need. One achievement seemed only achievable through downloading a savefile (check forums), at least it wouldn't work for me the proper way and seemed a common problem.Definitely recommended, at least if purchased on sale, and I will play the other games in the series (when they go on sale).My one nuisance with this game was after doubleclicking to auto-go to next place, Rufus would take a few seconds to stroll slowly into the screen before I could doubleclick move to next place. Really annoying if you're not sure what you're supposed to do where and check every place because walkthroughs are for uncool people.Art, sound & voices all good, music is pretty cool, even Rufus thinks so as one of his idle moves is air-guitaring to the currently played music.

Posted: October 1, 2015
												It has good things and not so good things.Things that I liked:- Good looking game, nice art.- Great music.- Interesting story, keeps me wanting to see more although it's unfinished...- Most puzzles are fair, not too hard but also not easy.Things that annoyed me:- The protagonist is a jerk. I don't hate him, but he could shut up sometimes, he keeps talking and talking every time you click anything, not alternative short lines when you click a second time, like in every other point 'n' click game.- The story is unfinished, the ending was really disappointing. And not just for the story, but also because it was rushed and anticlimactic, even the setting was depressing and dull. I already knew there are like 5 or 6 other games, but I thought at least the first one would have a satisfactory ending.- Every new scene throws too much stuff at you, it's confusing to have to visit like 5 different rooms filled with new stuff when you don't even have a clear idea of your objective. That's bad design and could be done better, just look at other games like Broken Sword or even Monkey Island, much better in that sense.- BUGS. This wasn't a problem until I got to the end of the game, where it kept crashing and I had to click like 3 or 4 times on a item in the inventory to select it. I ended up playing in windowed mode and it seemed to solve the crashing.Despite the annoying things I recommend the game, it's fun and the story is interesting, but keep in mind it is NOT finished, so get it on sale and then decide if you want to play the other games.

Posted: September 23, 2015
												Overall score: 8/10This game definitely has been a lot of fun.  The humor in it reminds me a lot of the Space Quest point and click adventure games from the 80's/90's with its silly humor.  It is graphically beautiful for the main stage being a futuristic wasteland that you live in.  Story line is quite humorous and well written.  The only thing that occasionally became annoying is it wasn't always clear on what you are supposed to be doing next to progress forward further into the story.  Definitely requires a lot of "out of the box" ways of thinking for some of the puzzles and figuring out how to use the objects you pick up.  For any fanatic of the classic point and click games, this will definitely bring you right back to it!

Posted: January 5, 2016
												Oh my, well I have to say I fell in LOVE with this game!Another gem from Daedalic & fans of point & click adventures will adore this.Pros:: Great soundtrack, from beginning to end it's really awesome how well thought {& well made} the music was.:: During game play, general movement & such is beautifully smooth:: Stunning art style - you can truly see how much work was put in to make Deponia look beautifully bleak:: Awesome characters - if you enjoy supreme amounts of sass with a main character, you won't be dissapointedCons:: This is more of a computer issue than an actual game fault issue {I assume anyway} - but during video cutscenes the frame rate was a bit terrible.  Just felt supremely laggy.  I wish there was an option to turn down the resolution to prevent the lag & aid other folks {similar to myself} who don't have the most awesome of computer set ups.:: I found at times during gameplay, Rufus {the main character} would randomly stop walking at points when I clicked on somewhere for him to go.  Most common places this happened was in Deponia city center area & the Mayors office {tried to click on the door to let me in, took like 4 tries}Other than that, I genuinely don't have many negative things to say about the game.I beyond loved this game, so much so that I took advantage of the steam sale & bought the 2nd & 3rd parts to the Deponia saga...  Even if it wasn't on sale, i'd happily throw all my money at steam to buy the full set, at full price.Would highly recommend that you invest in the saga!

Posted: December 21, 2015
												I can understand many of the points presented here. The pacing definitely is a bit off, and I completely agree about Kuvaq: They gave you the impression that it’s “just one more puzzle and then we can escape” the whole time, and that is kind of frustrating.What I absolutely can’t understand is that story, dialogue, animation and humour are being criticised. Those are the strong points of the game that actually make it one of the best classical adventure games I’ve played in a long time. The cutscenes are top notch and beautiful to look at, the characters are quirky and funny and just thinking of the scenes with the post robot going crazy on bubble wrap or the doctor “transforming” into a police officer makes me chuckle.The story was also misinterpreted, I think. Rufus actually is a pretty selfish guy, and you can’t possibly describe his relationship to Goal a romance. He treats her horribly and in the beginning it’s basically pure lust that drives him. Seeing how he slowly starts (!) to change is what made his character interesting.And concerning Rufus’ father, I’d say that it’s just not true that this plotline gets dropped. Just look at the ending and the characters involved… the cliffhanger ending ties everything together.Oh well. One last thing we agree on: This was merely an overture, the real adventure is just getting started. But personally, I’m very excited about that.Bless you, Droggeljug!

Beautiful. Entertaining. Addictive. It's all about this game. The game is addictive from the beginning and doesn't let go until the end. Posted: March 4, 2014
												A fun point & click adventure... not quite up to the Lucas Arts glory days, but still fun.You play as Rufus - oxygen thief pretty much sums him up, but so much so that he ends up being likeable.  The other characters are amusing and the world is interesting - a trash heap planent, a city in the sky & hints of class warfare:  I want to know more, so guess I'm going to have to play the other 2 games in the trilogy.For the most part, the puzzles make sense.  Where they don't & other characters don't give you helpful hints, you generally have few enough inventory items & interaction options to go through the trial & error grind without having too many murderous thoughts.  A nice touch to bypass any frustrating pixel hunting - pressing the spacebar shows you all the objects you can interact with.Overall, a nice diversion.  Not going to blow you away, but still worthwhile.

Posted: February 5, 2016
												This game... is AMAZING!!! When i completed it I felt sad bc i had grown attached to the character known as Rufus. Sure he is kind of a horrible person, but the levels of sass from him and from the other characters make the humor that much more unexpected. The puzzles are really engaging and deviously clever and you really have to sit there and think about how to get the right outcome because it will take you a while to figure out the puzzles. Posted: September 8, 2014
												Q: I say ol' chap, do you like point and click adventure games?A: Why, yes, yes I do!Q: Good show, and may I say, that is a smashing blouse you have on. Do you by chance like the indie cartoon art style in games that reminds you of Dragon's Lair?A: er...I'm not wearing a blouse but YES!! I LOVE DRAGONS LAIR!!...wait...is this where you are going to say that this game is none of those?Q: Why then you have come to the right place!! (plebian...).  This game has it all! The epic story line with this being the begining of the trilogy, whimsical puzzles, quirky humour that is a staple of this genre, the cheesy one liners from its awkward protagonist, the strong female damsel in distress who probably would have been better off if she had never met said main protagonist...A: But...Q: But....there are a number of bugs, especially *spoiler ol'chap* when you are on top of the post office. Trust me when I say that you should make a seperate save just before you enter the post office as there is a bug that doesn't always happen but it can where you can't climb back down the ladder. being stuck up there whilst doing a DroggleJug speed run is not fun, trust me. *end spoiler*A: So is it worth having?Q: Oh my my YES! its a must have of any fan of the genre, it even works quite well with a touch screen (played on a surface pro 3) although you dont have access to the space bar hint but then hints are for the WEAK!!...thinking about it...are'nt I supposed to be the one asking questions?A: You just did ask a question.Q: Jolly good. Ahhh all is right in the world once more *Pours a cool glass of Pimms* Cheers! and give'm what for ol' chap!Toodle pip

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Oh my, well I have to say I fell in LOVE with this game!Another gem from Daedalic & fans of point & click adventures will adore this.Pros:: Great soundtrack, from beginning to end it's really awesome how well thought {& well made} the music was.:: During game play, general movement & such is beautifully smooth:: Stunning art style - you can truly see how much work was put in to make Deponia look beautifully bleak:: Awesome characters - if you enjoy supreme amounts of sass with a main character, you won't be dissapointedCons:: This is more of a computer issue than an actual game fault issue {I assume anyway} - but during video cutscenes the frame rate was a bit terrible.  Just felt supremely laggy.  I wish there was an option to turn down the resolution to prevent the lag & aid other folks {similar to myself} who don't have the most awesome of computer set ups.:: I found at times during gameplay, Rufus {the main character} would randomly stop walking at points when I clicked on somewhere for him to go.  Most common places this happened was in Deponia city center area & the Mayors office {tried to click on the door to let me in, took like 4 tries}Other than that, I genuinely don't have many negative things to say about the game.I beyond loved this game, so much so that I took advantage of the steam sale & bought the 2nd & 3rd parts to the Deponia saga...  Even if it wasn't on sale, i'd happily throw all my money at steam to buy the full set, at full price.Would highly recommend that you invest in the saga!

Posted: December 21, 2015
												I can understand many of the points presented here. The pacing definitely is a bit off, and I completely agree about Kuvaq: They gave you the impression that it’s “just one more puzzle and then we can escape” the whole time, and that is kind of frustrating.What I absolutely can’t understand is that story, dialogue, animation and humour are being criticised. Those are the strong points of the game that actually make it one of the best classical adventure games I’ve played in a long time. The cutscenes are top notch and beautiful to look at, the characters are quirky and funny and just thinking of the scenes with the post robot going crazy on bubble wrap or the doctor “transforming” into a police officer makes me chuckle.The story was also misinterpreted, I think. Rufus actually is a pretty selfish guy, and you can’t possibly describe his relationship to Goal a romance. He treats her horribly and in the beginning it’s basically pure lust that drives him. Seeing how he slowly starts (!) to change is what made his character interesting.And concerning Rufus’ father, I’d say that it’s just not true that this plotline gets dropped. Just look at the ending and the characters involved… the cliffhanger ending ties everything together.Oh well. One last thing we agree on: This was merely an overture, the real adventure is just getting started. But personally, I’m very excited about that.Bless you, Droggeljug!

Posted: March 7, 2016
												There exists in el mundo much hating on the this game and the series as a whole, and I can see where they're coming from, but at least give it a chance.  If you like to indulge in a variety of both adolescent and mature comedy, have fun playing point and click games, or enjoy scratching your head, at least try the game out.  If an experienced (or at least moderately so,) point and click player, a substantial taste of the game is certainly achievable within steam refund playtime limit.RPSs review of the series past this game are not to be believed (as well as the lukewarm reception of this game) they harbor deep prejudice/not giving fair chance/failing to grasp game components correctly and John Walker should go walk off a cliff.I'm not going to give insight on the game 'cause its content is simply ineffable and must be experienced through your own gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												Daedalic is a well-respected name in the P&C (Point & Click) adventure game genre, so I hardly need to introduce them, so I'll just share my experiences with the game.Pros:+ Soundtrack and voice acting are a quality experience+ This of course would be meaningless without quality writing and humor+ You can double click some places you need to go in order to skip the transitions. Useful when you need to backtrack.+ The game won't automatically unlock "achievements" on you completing checkpoints, you actually have to find some of themCons:- Some logic leaps in gameplay. (spoiler) Like how am I supposed to know the funnel is the blowpipe when Deponia is a crapsack world with bits of tubing and pipes everywhere? (/spoiler) This will lead to... Trying everything with everything...- Sometimes going to an out-of-the-way location to pick up something you need to use somewhere else, at the other endFinal Verdict: 90/100No game is perfect, but Deponia certainly is not a waste of money.

Posted: October 22, 2015
												I like this game. It's so fiendishly clever. I admit that I had to use Gameboomer to get by certain spots but I enjoyed the game none the less. I bought the whole Deponia pack for $16 on the Steam special, so that's 11 games on the backlog.PROS1. StoryThe movie, Elysium, is like Deponia. The story of a Greek paradise in the afterlife. I was half-expecting Deponia to have a location called Tartarus.2. Tricky PuzzlesSolvable but you need to be extremely observant. Sometimes, some of the puzzles are very misleading. E.g. The meditation puzzle in the crane, who would know that putting a skeleton leg in the back of the seat would suffice for a yoga pose?3. ArtI like the simple art too.CONS1. Too ToughI have never seen a game that can get you stuck in for such a long time at a single point. The game doesn't give you good in-game hints to form items. Certain items like the Embellishment are so tiny that you can't even see them.2. Useless PuzzlesLike the levers next to the cotton candy machine. It's not fun to create portions of the game that do nothing but seem to be useful.

Posted: June 15, 2016
												I absolutely didn't imagine this game would interest and entertain as much as it did by the time I finished it. Deponia is a point-and-click adventure game with an interesting story and very diverse and likable characters. The puzzles are not that challenging if you've been keeping up with the genre but could get confusing for beginners (you can skip some of the puzzles but you'll lose their achievements!) I really can't find Rufus (the protagonist) unlikable like so many have stated. I actually really liked his character and the awesome writing helped a lot with making me feel at home with the wacky world. The entire game is nicely paced and feels really entertaining to play. Too bad there's not a whole lot of animation for all the characters or environments even though they all look like beautiful  paintings. All in all, This first game in the series was so interesting that I immediately purchased the remaining two titles from the trilogy in order to find out what happens next in this alluring series. Anybody with interest in the adventure genre or a vibrant world filled with humor owes it to themselves to at least try this one out.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												This is a very hesitant recommendation. For adventure game fans, Deponia has a lot to like: it's a beautiful game, for one. The artwork, animation and overall style is incredibly well done. The interface is also intuitive, utilizing the mouse wheel to quickly show and hide the inventory, and keeping interaction choices to either a left or right click (as opposed to early SCUMM games that would give you a load of often pointless ways with which to interact with objects).The puzzles are decent, although they'll occasionally have you doing things that don't make complete sense (you'll sometimes feel like you're not trying to solve a particular puzzle as much as just trying to figure out a hazy order of operations). To be fair though, the sometimes ambiguous nature of the puzzles may have been in part due to my not listening to all the dialogue options, which brings me to my main criticism of the game: the writing. Most of the characters are either irritating or generally unlikable, with a few who're downright obnoxious. The main character, Rufus, being the chief offender. I get that he's supposed to be an anti-hero who (presumably) finds his way over the course of the trilogy. However, after spending a few hours with him in the first game, I'm unsure I want to put myself through having to listen to his irritating whining and dopey commentary in the remaining two. It got to a point near the end of the game where I wanted to skip through every line of dialogue because I couldn't be bothered to listen to his idiotic responses. I sincerely hope he becomes more likable in the remaining two games.In conclusion, if you're a huge fan of adventure games, I'd say give Deponia a shot. If you're just mildly curious about the genre, give it a pass.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												A seriously entertaining point-and-click adventure game that is quite reminiscent of the Monkey Island series. Deponia features brilliant art direction, solid voice acting, and awesome soundtrack (Huzzah!). On the downside, like stated by many, the game is ridiculously short – I think it took like 5 hours in my first playthrough (apparently, this is the first installation of a trilogy, so fingers crossed for the next games). Even though the puzzles (which you can skip) are mostly fun, sometimes it gets quite tricky to find the right combination of items when you have to improvise – there were couple of instances where I gave up logic and instead tried every possible combination with the interactive objects. And when I finally figured them out, I was like “Seriously? Really?” But such instances were admittedly rare and definitely not the norm. On a somewhat surprising note, when I checked the texture compression option (which enables real-time compression), I started noticing a slight mouse lag and longer black screens during area transitions. Although it says that enabling that feature demands “high processing power”,  it’s funny to have a point-and-click game lag on a machine that runs the likes of the Witcher 2 or Crysis 3 with high/ultra settings (then again, it could be Windows 8.1 acting up as usual). Overall, highly recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2012
												A humorous 2D point & click adventure in which you play as Rufus, an inhabitant of the low-tech, junkyard city of Deponia who dreams of escaping to the advanced city of Elysium in the sky.  Early on an Elysian girl falls to Deponia and he sees this as his opportunity.  The game suffers from a slow start, but the story picks up later with some suspense & a satisfying ending. Progression is based on multi-screen environments and an inventory system, including combining/McGyvering items. It's a mix of common sense, critical thinking and trial and error. There is occasional frustration with sequence or dialogue, but you can click for audio commentary/hints on most things and press a key to see all the hotspots on screen.Beautiful, hand drawn art at 1080p with a minimalist interface that never feels cumbersome or gets in the way of the art, has Steam achievements and is fully voiced.

												I recommend playing this game to everyone who has fun with riddles. Not only are these riddle (in my opinion) made in a perfect balance between solvable and hard, but the whole story is filled with jokes and hilarious dialogues. content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												"Deponia" is a pretty good point-and-click game.  The art work is very good, the humor tongue-in-cheek, and the voice-acting good.  Best of all, the puzzles are neither too hard (mostly - there were a few I needed guides for) nor too easy.  My only real gripe with the game is the protagonist, Rufus:  he's a jerk of the first order.  If there were more character growth in him as the game progressed, I'd have been happier.  But, it's just sort of irritating to have him constantly do really wrong things at every turn.  As for the value of the game, I spent about 17.5 hours on it (100% Achievements).  So, the current list price (about $20) might be considered a tad high.  If you find it on sale, I'd say go for it.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												The main character is an unlovable piece of work. I get irritated just launching the game and looking at him, and so I can't find the motivation to finish the game. Perhaps he turns out to be some hero sort, but his current whiny, pompous self makes me feel so annoyed I can't ever see him being one short of being an "accidental hero" (at this point I hate him so much that that thought also annoys me). He is unsympathisable.In addition, I enjoy point-and-click puzzles when the puzzles are canon to the story and make sense (e.g. find the key, the key is with the guard, find a way to distract the guard). Puzzles in Deponia are more of those logic-puzzle based sort – whole lot of pattern recognition, switch flipping, make all the dots on the board green from red sort, which means sometimes the object you need isn't logically related to the task. It is overwhelmingly repetitive and feels pointless.If you're looking for a good adventure point-and-click, try Chains of Satinav instead, from the same developers. Superb artwork, top-notch voice acting, enthralling storytelling and most importantly puzzles that are innovative and logical to the storyline.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												If you were stuck on a planet filled with nothing but junk and surrounded by idiots you’d want to escape right? Well if so then this is the game for you.Help poor Rufus make his dream a reality and escape the junk ridden world of Deponia and make it all the way to the lofty heights of Elysium a floating city high above. And along the way meet a few new friends and enemies to boot. The story is pretty good and full of jokes and gags. I loved the writing and thought it was very well done. The characters are great too, each adding to the overall zaniness. Deponia is a point a click game and as such the gameplay is pretty standard for the genre. The puzzles are not overly challenging but you may well be stumped a few times on the journey but each and every time you figure it out you feel pretty darn good. Clicking on everything that seems interesting to find all the needed objects and combining items together to overcome every obstacle can be very satisfying.  The game looks great; the art style is very unique and cartoony. Every set piece, character and item all fits nicely into the decaying world in which the game takes place. I loved exploring people’s homes and seeing what was used to build such wacky places. The game runs great, but as mentioned it’s a cartoon so there isn’t much the computer needs to generate. The game sounds great too; the music is fun and catchy. The sound effects are pretty comical and fit well in the title and every character is very well acted. I thought they all worked well together.Although not ground breaking or particularly long it is a thoroughly enjoyable title from start to finish. I had great fun with it. At full price it’s a little steep but that being said if you like point and click or love the way the game looks or the comedy then go ahead and dive in. For the rest of us I’d wait for a sale, but it’s worth a look and will give you a few laughs.Have fun ^_^

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
Great artstyle, great puzzles, great voice acting, great setting. Truely, a fantastic Point 'N' Click.However, although the puzzles padded out the game, the plot didn't catch up. Not too much happens. Well...NPCs give bits of lore, but the dialogue is unfortunately just repetetive banter with the protagonist. Although well written/translated, hearing the NPCs scold or embarrass the self-absorbed protagonist is just dull.The mosaic minigame was bugged and impossible to complete. Luckily, there was a skip option. Which, to be honest, makes all of the (few) minigames fruitless.If you've read all the above, it may seem like I am bashing the game. I'm not. Deponia, and its sequels, are a must-have for any patient gamer. And even Rufus manages to grow on you.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												Know what you are getting into.I bought this game at a large discount as part of a bundle of similar games by the same people.I have no doubt that this game is well-made - the characters are quirky, the dialogue is (somewhat) witty, and the story is, well... odd - which is part of what interested me in it.However, it is, at times, slow and frustrating. To being with, the path forward required a little thinking (try this, try that, combine some items to see what they do). Now, however, I'm at the point where I am literally talking to every character and exploring every room to see if I have missed something.While I enjoyed this game for a while, overall I found the puzzles obtuse. If that's the kind of thing you like, then great! But if you are more interested in the characters or the story, then I would suggest you try something else.Every time I play this game, I make a *little* more progress. I find an item combination that unlocks another line of dialogue - the next step in the puzzle. But it takes 10 to 20 minutes or random trial and error, and for me that's just not fun.Of course, the other option is to look up solutions online... but if that's the approach I was looking for I would have just bought a visual novel instead. Perhaps the game is simply more suited to experienced puzzle-gamers?Overall: 7/10Much of the game is great. However, some of the puzzles are very non-intuitive, and until you figure them out, the story cannot progress. Buy this only if you are willing to be patient and persistent.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												Played through the opening thus far, and I had to go check out some other reviews of this and the later games.  I needed to know if things were going to get better.  The things that had attracted me to the purchase hadn't changed; beautiful art, great voicework, that old adventure touch.  But on playing the game, I found that, well, the protaganist is completely unlikable.He's essentially a sociopath, and much of the humor is trying to play off of that.  From relentless abuse (from verbal to theft) of his Ex-Girlfriend to just blowing some people's houses up so you can take their place in a line, the Protaganist treats everything with egomanical contempt.  You're genuinely meant to find this behavior funny, but this game just doesn't work without something redeeming to latch onto.  At the end of the day, you're assisting a throughly unlikable person do generally unpleasent things, for 'humor'.  As to those reviews, I was hoping to find that he'd build towards that epifany moment and start to show some undercurrent of a likable person.  The counterpoint that makes putting up the rest funny, or at least bearable.Unfortuantly, that doesn't ever seem to happen.  Rather, the game and particularly its sequals simply ramp up the acrimony.  Sale purchase so I can't complain too harshly, but this is one of the few games I've ever ran across that I genuinely regret purchasing.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
Insane Adventure Game Logic: now with weird European humor!The characters and setting are interesting enough that I'll probably watch a playthrough video, but having to check a walkthrough every few minutes to figure out what insane thing you have to do gets old FAST.For example, before you're allowed to leave the first area, Rufus has to collect four items to pack into his suitcase. Bringing a clean pair of socks seems easy - I found a blue and a yellow sock, but Rufus wanted a matching pair. Okay... Rufus says they're dirty, so let's try washing them in boiling water, which results in the two socks coming out as ONE green sock. I had to check a walkthrough to find out that there's another green sock completely hidden under Rufus' pillow... did I mention that the game is set on a garbage planet, but the few items that you can actually interact with aren't highlighted? (edit: apparently there's a button you can press to highlight items you can interact with... quality UI design!)One of the other four items you need to pack is Rufus' toothbrush, which comes alive and runs and hides because of how filthy Rufus' teeth have been on the rare times he's brushed them. Okay, I can live with the idea of a sentient toothbrush, heck as a kid I even used to watch a cartoon with that exact premise. So how would you think that an adventure game would have you lure out an abused toothbrush? Maybe by tempting it with nice teeth to brush, such as by somehow convincing another character (with superior dental hygiene) to smile near the toothbrush? Nope, you catch it with a mousetrap... with a pea for bait. What?! And you find that mousetrap in a "closet" which just looks like part of the wall (did I mention how visually messy the garbage planet setting is?). The game implies that you need something to pry the closet door open, and the required tool turns out to be a TOILET PLUNGER.I think that was when I gave up on the game.
