content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												I thought I would like this game because it had good reviews and was compared to the Monkey Island series. Instead we have a game that's misogynist, transphobic and obtuse with a main character so unlikeable that I just gave up on the game. I didn't care about the fact that it had hard puzzles or ones that made no sense. I was expecting that, but Rufus is such a♥♥♥♥♥♥that I'm sad I even spent two bucks on this game. You can tell that they put a lot of work into it. I love the art in the game, I like the way that it looks and it sounds (voice acting aside), but... I just can't get past how juvenile and bigoted the humour is. Maybe that's the point. Maybe it's trying to be ironic in the way of South Park by being absolutely horrible for comedic effect and to draw attention to how stupid these tropes/stereotypes/etc sound. But the problem with Deponia trying to do that? It's not funny. The jokes fall flat, the dialogue gets painful to listen to and I have never wished so much that there was a big cliff that I could just throw Rufus off over and over again.

And it was fun at first.BUT: Then came the Adventuring part. Taking everything you see, trying to combine it and somehow figure out how to use something on something else. At first I've tried to figure everything by myself. Later I've started to look at the guide, here and there. And after a while I've found myself looking at it more or less constantly. Those things just don't make any sense to me. I don't know why would I knock out a parrot with laughing gas and I don't know what I would do with him afterwards.I don't doubt that Deponia is a great game. For people who like adventure games. But if you don't like adventure games, Deponia isn't for you despite how gorgeous it looks, how funny it can be, and how great the voice acting is.I'm really sad that I couldn't enjoy it. But I won't play game by reading a guide.

number of helpful: 18 of 35 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												While the art is cool, and the world concept is a fun one, the gross sexism in this game made it completely horrible to play.  Female characters are only there as a joke or a quest, and the writing continually enforces this attitude.   Hell, the main female character is CALLED Goal.  *eyeroll*  And the driving force for Rufus is to win her.   As well as this, Rufus constantly tells us that cleaning is a woman's role (specifically his ex Toni) and that "girly things" are beneath  him.  There's also a trans woman played as a joke ("ha ha look at the big man in a dress"  Yeah, no, not actually funny.)Clearly this is all meant to be funny, and to endear Rufus to us as a "charming rogue".  A clue, it doesn't, he isn't.  He's a creeper, and the way he acts towards the unconcious/brain damaged Goal is creepy, gross, bordering on rapey.  His friend Wendel is also nasty.    The whole game has a greasy vibe.  It's a real shame, because technically it's not a bad game.  The movement is a bit slow and clunky, and it can be frustrating to get from one point to another,  but otherwise it does okay.  I would have been interested to play similar games if the whole thing didn't leave me feeling like I needed a shower.  As it is, don't bother.  Spend your money on a game that gives its female characters some agency, and its male characters some redeeming character traits.So very glad I got this on sale, not worth it.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Deponia is a point-and-click adventure reminiscent of the infamous Monkey Island series. The game is part of a trilogy (Deponia -> Chaos On Deponia -> Goodbye Deponia). You play Rufus, the archetypical anti-hero whose bad jokes are only matched by his failed attempts to leave his junk covered planet Deponia. While the story unfolds you will be busy searching that single missing item to progress, creating thought provoking item combinations and solving mind boggling puzzles. All-in-all an entertaining game, but certainly not up to par with Monkey Island. Good enough to start playing Chaos On Deponia. :)Score: 7/10Pro:+ nice cartoonish look & feel+ entertaining story+ decent voice acting+ absurd humourContra:- bad humour- clicking feels so 1990... ;)

content:

												Awesome point'n'click adventure looking to be compared to the old 2D classics such as the Monkey Island series (1-3) and the Lucas Arts ones. Doesn't even hide their influence, which is good, for the puzzles are good, the humor involved is hilarious (well... if you're not very sensitive) and the graphics... Oh, the graphics! Beautiful hand drawn backgrounds, fitting colours and the funky animation just takes me back 20 years, when these games were thriving. Also the songs are fantastic.Aside from a couple bugs (which have been all but fixed) I recommend it 100 %. If you like adventure games, you won't be disappointed. Parts 2 and 3 (Chaos on Deponia and Goodbye Deponia) follow in it's steps too.

												BEFORE ANYTHING ELSE: IF YOU DOUBLE CLICK ON THE EXITS, YOU WILL MOVE TO THE NEXT SCREEN IMMEDIATELY, YOU DON'T HAVE TO WAIT FOR RUFUS TO WALK ALL THE WAY!Hopefully this will get a chance to help people, I had the hardest time watching Rufus all the way across the center of the town.I think this is another great piece of work from Daedalic Entertainment. Wonderful artwork and music as always. Difficult puzzles but nothing out of the unexpected if you have played any games from Daedalic.At the beginning, the plot may seem a bit confusing since the setting does not get explained further on into the story. It's kind of hard to grasp the concept of Deponia and Elysium until later of the story. The first half of the game may seem a bit boring but the story is amazing if you could hold onto it until the very end.What I do find interesting is that the protagonist is not your usual all-mighty or pure-hearted wonderful person. Rufus is an a-hole that does not have a job and nor does he appreciate his ex's help. Unfortunately the story does not tell into too much of Rufus past and explain why he may have became like that. Hopefully I will have time to play Chaos in Deponia very soon to find out more.

Posted: May 23, 2015
												BEFORE ANYTHING ELSE: IF YOU DOUBLE CLICK ON THE EXITS, YOU WILL MOVE TO THE NEXT SCREEN IMMEDIATELY, YOU DON'T HAVE TO WAIT FOR RUFUS TO WALK ALL THE WAY!Hopefully this will get a chance to help people, I had the hardest time watching Rufus all the way across the center of the town.I think this is another great piece of work from Daedalic Entertainment. Wonderful artwork and music as always. Difficult puzzles but nothing out of the unexpected if you have played any games from Daedalic.At the beginning, the plot may seem a bit confusing since the setting does not get explained further on into the story. It's kind of hard to grasp the concept of Deponia and Elysium until later of the story. The first half of the game may seem a bit boring but the story is amazing if you could hold onto it until the very end.What I do find interesting is that the protagonist is not your usual all-mighty or pure-hearted wonderful person. Rufus is an a-hole that does not have a job and nor does he appreciate his ex's help. Unfortunately the story does not tell into too much of Rufus past and explain why he may have became like that. Hopefully I will have time to play Chaos in Deponia very soon to find out more.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2013
												Deponia, Chaos on Deponia, and Goodbye Deponia are point and click adventure games of old with a set of truly beautiful scenes and music.  The game and its series aims for classless humor and heavy amounts of schadenfreude.   If you're sensitive to any civil rights, human rights, animal rights, rights for the infirm, and rights of the wrongly convicted, you're likely to get offended at some point in this series.  You play as Rufus, a perpetual underdog that doesn't really seem to grasp that he's the underdog.  While he can be hard to relate to at times, especially in his moments of abscent minded cruelty, he has his good moments.   The female lead character is cheekedly called 'Goal,' which an obvious jab at other games where the female lead characters are often 'finish lines' rather than anything meaningful.  She stays true to her name throughout a fair bit of the first game, but becomes a living character towards the end of the first, and throughout the second and third games.Deponia itself is a giant junkyard underneath a utopia-like society, not unlike worlds of Astroboy, and Battle Angel Alita, and Rufus is absolutely a man of his world.  The series is a long stream of "connect the odds and ends to make things work" like many other games in the genre, and the theme of the game fits perfectly in the genre.Ultimately, it's a fun ride.  The story and the humor, much like the "water" in Deponia, might leave a strange taste in your mouth, but its worth investing your time in.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Deponia is a strong game in terms of point and click mechanics. It's that sweet spot between when puzzles are obvious and impossibly mind numbingly hard. But Deponia is a game I can recommend to certain people but not a game I can recommend to everyone. The puzzles aren't so clever that you would be playing the game for them. It's driven by its story which is dominated by European style humour. Every review I've seen for it has been bimodal from, "Hilarious game" to "bad joke after bad joke". It's a game that really should have a demo so that people can see whether the story has a draw for them. Since that doesn't really exist, I'd recommend check out a part 1 walkthrough of some sort since its price is pretty steep. I'd also recommend waiting for the whole pack of Deponia's to go on sale because it does end with a cliffhanger and if you enjoy it, you're going to want to follow it through.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												This game was a lot of fun.  I played this with my kids and we had a blast.  It was humourous (a little tacky at times) and reminded me of earlier games in this genre.  Most of the time it was clear what we needed to do to progress, but in some cases the puzzles are a bit obscure (this seemed to occur more in the sequels in this series).The main character, Rufus is an arrogant resident of Deponia trying to leave for a better life.  Although it can be sometimes hard to truly cheer on this idiot, the quirkiness of the story and the game's puzzles keep you interested just to see what kind of trouble this guy is going to get into next.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												This game is amazing! A very nice script and a great atmosphere. If you like point-and-click adventures with wits and and a funny story line this one might be the one for you!The game is full of references from movies and popular cultures, so I suggest to take your time while playing it. Graphic is lovely (although the animations somehow sloppy, but nothing that is gonna kill the gaming experience) and the design very interesting. The puzzles will sometimes drive you nuts, because they often require an outside-the-box approach.Note that this is just the first part of a story developed throught 3 different games (Chaos on Deponia and Goodbye Deponia follow!), so you might with to buy them together.But, hell. This is fun!

It's an OK game, but it has a few glitches, but you can play it.  Preferably with a guide to make it pass more quickly.Don't know if I would recommend it or not.  It would depend upon an individual

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												If you're looking for a stinking bath to dip yourself in, you have found your way.Painful overusage of tropes makes this a waste of your time. Please don't buy it if you're at all concerned about what kind of media you spend your time on. The protagonist of this game is horrible. The puzzle logic is horrible. The plot is flat. The worst part of this all is that the game is concious of all of the above but either chooses to ignore it, or critiques it in such a way that it's not a critique anymore but a mockery. Theft, absurd sexism, transphobia, animal abuse, abuse of persons and tools, ignorance, shallow remarks and little to no actual substance or even sparks of intelligence are present, all wrapped in a neat, attractive bundle of vague definition of what the devs concidered "fun". Non of this is particularly visual (except animal abuse), but it leaves a bad taste in your mouth for quite a while. It's hard to believe that someone could talk proudly about this game as their work. After stong references to Machinarium I am nothing but disappointed. This kind of animation, voice acting and soundtrack deserved better imho.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2013
												A much better visual than Primordia, the first thought that sprung in my mind when I first played the game. Excuse me but I need to save my eyes from getting more damage from broken visuals. Graphic looks like to be a hand drawn - my preference really. Sometimes comical style game is alot better than advanced looking AAAs.Game is a point and click genre - one of my favorite type to do casually in between dota matches or doing serious AAA titles like jumpscare Dead Space series. Game's full with satirical humor that brings lots of facepalm moment. It's not bad, though, in fact I quite enjoy the story and the humor. Being a point and click, gameplay isn't that complicated. Although yes, this is more expansive than The Walking Dead - despite some elements are the same - but the 'puzzles' are a bit more tedious and ridiculous (helloooooooooo why do I have to capture a hiding fork????). And somewhat frustrating if you're really clueless on what to do. But eh, again, it's pretty much fine since we have walkthrough or videos in all around internet. No big deal.Overall, to my surprise and initial negative view on the game, this is a pretty much ok title. Too bad this isn't a type that allows you to sit back and enjoy with the controller - the game's much easier to play with MK/B than a gamepad.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												The game is ___very___ offensive.  Saying that the protagonist is a jerk would be a serious ___understatement___.  The entire game and everything therein revolves around the idea that women should be treated as sex object no better than perosnal property: it's disgusting! It's degrading to __both__ men and women.  Men are not _necessarily_ slobs or jerks, and women do _not_ exist just so that men can dehumanize, exploit, abuse, or treat them like objects existing only to provide labor/pleasure for men.  I read a few blogs, some of which were written by feminists, and (while I do not condone the idea of either sex being superior in anyway to the other) I heartily and thoroughly agree with what I read.  DO ___NOT___ BUY THIS GAME.  It's an insult to human deceny!

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												This is a fun adventure. You play Rufus who just want to get to Elysium and off Deponia, a planet full of dump and waste. The planet is thought to be uninhabited and ought to be destroyed by the Organon. But as it happens one of your tries to escape the planet had actually succeed in landing on an Organon cruiser. You and accidentally also the girl Goal from Elysium are dropped again on the planet’s surface. Your task is to a) save Goal, b) get Goal to Elysium to report that there is still life on Doponia and c) get yourself off the planet.This can’t be hard, could it? Well it is. Since Rufus, your character, is a blighter, boaster, a loafer, which always exaggerated the opinion of himself. He can’t do nothing good and his tries to get off the planet as well as his inventions usually end up in total catastrophes. This is stuff for a lot of funny conversations and hilarious dialogues. The (german) voice acting is brilliant.The planet, its people and also Rufus do entertain and are not without sympathy. The riddles are sometimes quite hard to solve and I did some by pure trial & error (which is no good).Controlling the game is clever made, the scenarios are nice drawn and there is no room for a technical reproach.8/10.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2013
												A much better visual than Primordia, the first thought that sprung in my mind when I first played the game. Excuse me but I need to save my eyes from getting more damage from broken visuals. Graphic looks like to be a hand drawn - my preference really. Sometimes comical style game is alot better than advanced looking AAAs.Game is a point and click genre - one of my favorite type to do casually in between dota matches or doing serious AAA titles like jumpscare Dead Space series. Game's full with satirical humor that brings lots of facepalm moment. It's not bad, though, in fact I quite enjoy the story and the humor. Being a point and click, gameplay isn't that complicated. Although yes, this is more expansive than The Walking Dead - despite some elements are the same - but the 'puzzles' are a bit more tedious and ridiculous (helloooooooooo why do I have to capture a hiding fork????). And somewhat frustrating if you're really clueless on what to do. But eh, again, it's pretty much fine since we have walkthrough or videos in all around internet. No big deal.Overall, to my surprise and initial negative view on the game, this is a pretty much ok title. Too bad this isn't a type that allows you to sit back and enjoy with the controller - the game's much easier to play with MK/B than a gamepad.

number of helpful: 17 of 35 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												The music in this game is really well done, and the puzzles are generally funny and well thought out. My biggest issue with the entire series is the underlying racism and sexism that it presents throughout the three Deponia games. It is fairly disturbing encountering a puzzle where you need to sell the only black character in the series into slavery, because she could best mimic an organ grinder's monkey, for instance. More disturbing is that the designers saw this as the "out of the box, yet still obvious solution". Similarly, the whole mechanic in the second game where the female protagonist's personality is split into its three core components of "sporty" "baby" and "stuck up" is emblematic of the kinds of criticisms for the endemic sexism that the gaming community has been receiving in the media of late.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
												I tend to like these types of games, and usually can get an easy recommendation from me.  Deponia has some decent humor to it, but will constantly do little things to annoy the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you.  Many of the puzzles just simply don't make sense.  It may seem completely obvious that doing something you have in mind should work, but the writers would rather you do it their way, which makes less sense.  This is a minor flaw, though.  The bigger flaw is that the game is downright buggy.  If you skim through the discussion forums you'll see a lot of problems the game has, and the devs only solution is to download a new save file.  Even with known issues, the game doesn't seem to get patched, and you're simply stuck with downloading a different save file, which could throw your own game out of sequence.  I usually want to complete games like this, but this has made me lose my motivation to finish it, even as I have the sequels in my library waiting to be played, but will now likely never be installed.

number of helpful: 14 of 29 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												As fan of adventure games, and one who has grown up on Monkey Island series and later games like Full throttle and Sanitarium, I was excited about playing this game... until 5 minutes in, when I got stuck first time. Ok, I google-it, found solution and continue on... for next 5 min, until I got stuck AGAIN! And after looking up on google for solution once more, I figured out system how this game works; enter area, play pixel hunting to find all clickable items so that you can collect them, then try out all items from inventory on all noncollectable items in that room, and if that doesn't work, then try to combine all items in your inventory one with another till you get new item. When you craft new item, try him out with everything in room, and then with everything in your inventory (because sometimes you have to combine more items to get something useful)... And if after all of that, you didn't do anything that will progress story further on, go to next area and repeat procedure. And you have to do all of that due to twisted and borderline insane logic behind all puzzles in this game, so there is very little things that will be logical at first (or ever).So, does that sound like fun? For me it didn't... So I grabbed first walk-trough I found online, and finished game with it, and that makes me sad because characters (except main character), visuals, humor, animation and atmosphere are wonderful... Shame.And I really can't say that I liked main character in this game (he is borderline sociopath); maybe they intended to do that, but It just make me dislike him in general, and If I don't like main character, I tend to like game less (this is personal preference, so take that that in consideration). And there are some questionable moral agendas in this game regarding females....Overall, I don't recommend this game, due to insane puzzles that barely make any sense, and they reduce game to tedious clicking and trying out everything on everything until you make something new.Score: 4/10

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												I'll fully admit I bought this for the art style. In that regard, Deponia is exactly what it advertises. The chunky, eccentric designs of characters and backgrounds really brings this game to life.And that's where the praise ends.The big issue here is the writing, and it commits what is, to me, the greatest sin. It's trying to be funny. The jokes come at you on a regular basis. But I did not laugh once in my entire playthrough. Perhaps it's because of the mean nature of much of the humor, or it's a style that just doesn't carry over in translation, but most of the time the characters just seemed unlikable and mean-spirited.My thought is that if you don't get laughs, stop it. Just stop it. Tell a story, be earnest in your delivery, drop all the affected attempts at hilarity. Maybe then they could have spent more time on the puzzles, which range from arbitrary to insulting.There's a puzzle where you literally have to make an association between the house a person lives in and what their hat is, because three people all have headgear that looks like their occupation. It's that sort of backwards engineered idiot puzzle that makes people give up on adventure games. It has to be logical, sensible but not obvious, or the player will just give up.This is the sort of series I'd rather view through one of those "Let's Play" Youtube series, but preferrably with the sound off.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												My oh my... I mean, this game does have neat visuals. And sometimes it is funny. The puzzles are moderate in obscurity and difficulty.On the other hand the main character (Rufus) is the most obnoxious, arrogant, sexist and stubborn main character I have ever seen. It was very hard playing as him and hear him make simple, often unfunny and unnecessary comments. And the way he talks about women... He despises the first one even though she (god knows why) literally provides the roof above his head, and the other one he treats as if she were his property. Besides that, the game is riddled with dirty humour and a story that really makes no sense and gives no explanation.I would have loved it if as the game progressed, Rufus evolved and became humbler and reasonable. But no. And thus, I would not recommend, unless you really only care about the puzzles or do not care about depth of character.

content:

												The protagonist will steal everything he sees, flood his friend's house, poison his former girlfriend with dart(who is supporting him economically), frame a mayor, and abuse animals. Also, the post office of this town makes cats work by literally shocking them with electricity. Yes, really.All these small details might be funny to some people, but it was very bizarre to me, even unpleasant. Not only Rufus, the protagonist(I would never use a word 'hero' on this guy), but the atmosphere of this game also doesn't give a shxt about all these madness he's making everywhere, as if it's just some kind of a joke.To me, it was a very ill-humored joke. Giving it red for that reason.p.s.Surprisingly, there's a good reason for his attitude, which is revealed at Deponia 3. Well, it's a review for Deponia 1 though. If you are going to play all Deponia titles, ignore this review. If you are not, beware that the main charater might let you down.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												I've seen what this game has to offer, though not on Steam. Trust me: Deponia is the Adam Sandler of adventure games. Sometimes, it creeps up to being the Will Farrell of adventure games. More often, it's somewhere in the middle, like Ben Stiller. At no point is it really all that fun for any length of time. Graphics aren't everything, but they're everything to Deponia.  Once you get past the screenshots, there are no redeeming qualities to the game. Generally, Deponia involves a clunky, unattractive interface, stupid amounts of not-just-difficult-but-illogical puzzles, a plot that creeps forward like molasses in January, an unattractive protragonist and an unfunny script. Go play a fun adventure game, like Broken Age, or Full Throttle, or the Monkey Island games. Stay away from Deponia. At best, buy it and watch a Let's Play.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												This is a fantastic point-n-click adventure game. If you've played any of the old LucasArts or Sierra adventure games from the 90's, you'll feel right at home with Deponia. It's art style and sense of humor is reminiscient of Monkey Island or Day of the Tentacle, and its puzzles are definitely challenging without being outlandishly obscure. It's a perfect balance of logic and wackiness. The story and characters are also well done, though it took a little bit for the main character, Rufus, to grow on me (he's obnoxious and grating at first). Since this is part 1 of a trilogy, the ending will leave you hanging and wanting more. However, don't let that fool you into thinking it cuts short. I finished this in 12 hours, which is unheard of for point-n-click games in this day and age. If you loved the adventure games in the 90's from LucasArts or Sierra, this is definitely worth your time and money, and I can't wait to play the sequels.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Three minutes into the game, tears man; tears!!! I was laughing so hard I couldn't catch my breath. The game takes me back to my childhood. Similar to Monkeys Island the game has a funny story that keeps you going throughout the GamePlay. Main character of the game Ruffes is a story of its own. Clumsy, maniacal, stubborn guy that has a neck for getting in to trouble yet he desperately tries to "save" the love of his life and get his happy ending. Mini games are also something worth mentioning. They are fun to play and give you a little brainless break from your main adventure. Last but not least is the music that follows you into every chapter of the game and stays in your head for days after ending this game. Deponia is a great game and I can't wait to finish the whole trilogy. The game still has a lot of room for improvement so I'm going to give it 6/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2012
												I like Point & Click Adventures. I love how they tell their stories and create their worlds. But I must make an admission about me and this genre.I cheat profusely at Adventure games...To me its the destination thats more crucial to Adventure games than the journey. It takes away from the overall experience if I have to try every item on my inventory on everything in the environment. so apologies to those who object me to using walkthroughs. Moving on....Deponia's story is an interesting one. Rufus, a do nothing, egotistical and self-involved young man who desperately wants to leave his stinking junkyard homeworld Deponia for the utopian floating city of Elysium. His latest hair brained plan to escape almost succeeded had he gets involved in an incident and rescues a mysterious girl, knocking her into a coma in the process. Its a funny and light hearted story with a touching cast that still delivers some swift plot twists and one liners (all voiced as well). All of which is pleasingly punctuated by the games detailed, cartoon art style that takes you in (with some help from the music....).Gameplay is as it has always been for Point & Clicks; you study the scene, collect everything and solve esoteric puzzles that put the Gordian Knot to shame. I'm not gonna delve too much into it since I use walkthroughs. But I will say its a fair bit better controls than other adventure games I've played.Deponia is a fun game, but like all Point & Click adventures its not for everyone. More for the inquisitive type in it for the story than the action. I'm already ready too dive into the sequel.As well as finish The Secret of Monkey Island...

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												Really adorable character designs, interesting storyline peppered with silly one-liners... I really wanted to like this game, I wanted to be so into it that I bought the sequels. The puzzles were appropriate at progressing the plot, not too easy nor complex... then the emergency phone in the centre of town didn't have a click option so I had to reload saves then replay from the start to find it had ironed out. Then I was condemned to a replaying cutscene before reaching the station that made my character return to the control room like I had completed a puzzle incorrectly when I hadn't. Over and over I had to try to push past it. I don't mind a few bugs but then I uninstalled when I reached the whale. Why? Because the puzzle seemed forced like someone just wanted to extend the gameplay and I realised, so close to the end, the game had lost it's spark. Inventive and sweet to look at, I want to recommend it but cannot as it hooked me in and just completely dulled me out.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2013
												Deponia is a standard point and click adventure with a lot of witty humor. It’s not a very long game but it has an interesting story and it will give you a few laughs. You play as Rufus, who is a self-centered lowlife and his main goal is to get out of the dump Deponia to live in Elysium. Somehow along the way things go wrong of course. The puzzles aren’t too hard to understand and some puzzles even have an option to skip them. I thought the voice acting was pretty good and the game has some clever cartoony visuals. If you like point and click adventures games you definitely should play Deponia.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Deponia has a great story and really humorous characters. This is the first point and click adventure game I've played in a long time, and while the genre is not my favorite, it was a very enjoyable experience. One of my favorite aspects about the game was the mystery which surrounded Elysium and the futuristic, upper class society which runs it. The majority of the puzzles can be figured out in a mostly straight forward manner, I only had to cheat by looking at a walkthrough a few times. The main character, Rufus, reminded me of a more egocentric Fry from Futurama and I suppose the art style also reminded me of the TV series. The game made me laugh out loud a handful of times and often put a smile on my face, it was perfect, just like me.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												When this game showed up on my radar, it had *sooo* much potential to be the next Monkey Island. While it doesn't completely fall short, it does enough wrong to not get my vote.Pros:-Art style is really polished. -Music (especially intro) is surprisingly good.-Length is about what point-and-click adventures should be.-The idea of calling a trilogy from the begining is a great idea.Cons:-I need my point-and-click adventures to be more or less logic driven. What I mean is that the items I try to use to solve the problem should make some sort of sense (even if it is quite tangential). This game suffers very badly from matching up logic to solve problems. Alot of the time it ends up being random clicking that gets you through. This is not very satisfying.-There is some sort of language barrier as some of the jokes are questionable lol. I find it funny but I would be willing to bet that the humor/script was written for another culture (I am located in North America).I also played the second game in the trilogy, and will not be visiting the third. Not a complete waste of time, but there are better games out there (plus I payed the full 20$ asking price).

content:
Posted: December 30, 2012
												A surprisingly good adventure game. If you're already an adventure game fan, this is definitely one to pick up. The story is good enough, the comedy is there, the voice acting is, for the most part good, barring a couple of characters and most importantly, the puzzles are logical. Chances are, if you get stuck, you'll find out the answer and be slapping your own forehead, than throwing the game out the window. This is a game, however, where pressing spacebar to reveal hotspots could save a few of those head slapping moments. I'll be waiting to pick up Chaos on Deponia.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Short version: This is a good game, but if you don't have any of them, the Complete Journey is a much better investment. The games integrate well together, there are more achievements, and it's available on more platforms.This is just a cut down version of my review for the Complete Journey.By now you've probably heard some things about these games and about how the creators are the "German Lucasarts" [which seems a bit unfair given there isn't an American Lucasarts any more].Well, I for one really enjoyed these games. There was a good balance between outright comedy and drama and the design and animation is top-notch, and it seems to be impossible to get stuck or killed.The first game is not as good as the second and third though. I found Rufus to be a bit of a jerk and rather unlikeable, the backgrounds pretty though mostly static, and the puzzles largely illogical. Oh, and the game seemed to suffer from the same problem that Simon the Sorcerer did. It thinks it's funnier than it is.The creators do seem to have made point-and-click adventures their "thing", and rather than Telltale who seem to have rounded all the corners off and made their games simpler for a new generation, Deponia is aimed squarely at people who enjoyed these games when they were in their heyday. That doesn't mean they're old-fashioned though. The control interface is reasonably straight forward, the games are gorgeous (did I mention that?), the voice acting is excellent and the music is..well, it's alright. You can switch it off if it gets on your nerves.I'm not going to compare the game to Monkey Island. Just because it's a point-and-click game doesn't mean it has to be like a Lucasarts game. It's not as wacky as Cokel's Gobliiins series, nor is it as serious as The Dig. Perhaps it's more like Sam and Max, with the gleefully anti-social protagonist. Regardless, if you like point-and-click games and want something with a good storyline and hours of gameplay, it's difficult to go wrong with this.

content:
Posted: January 3
Bottom line up-front:Should you buy this game: If you enjoy point-and-click adventures, YesPro's:+ Great art syle+ Memorable, but brief characters+ Funny story with a likable protagonist.+ Good music with original songsCon's+ Obstuse puzzle solutions+ Short story legnth+ Not enough interation with many unique charactersReviewDeponia (first in a series of four games) is at its heart, a throw-back to the early point and click adventure games first popularized by Sierra-Online in the 80's and early 90s'. It follows the misadventures of Rufus, a self-centered, self-aggrandizing, self-destructive, yet lovable transient bum, who is trying desperately to escape the perpetual junk filled planet of Deponia for the floating paradise in the sky known as Elysium. As the opening exposition tells us on the outset of the game, he will concoct any manner of schemes or contraptions in order to achieve his goal, and Lord help anyone, or anything that stands in his way.  I just wish I had a chance to interact with them more and see them fleshed out more fully.And speaking of goals, Rufus quickly crosses paths with Goal, a beautiful Elysium woman who is, shall we say...not right in the head.  Which as Rufus will attest, that her condition had absolutely nothing to do with knocking her off the unprotected deck of a passing cruiser deck, plummeting to the ground and damaging her brain's hardware, rendering her unconscious. Goal represents the more cultured and educated foil to Rufus's blunt and unrefined nature, but the revelation later that her memories and personality can be changed via data cartriges placed in her brain implant, seemed a little off-putting.  I realize that it was written that way for comedic effect, but it still created a few cringeworthy moments.What follows is Rufus' travels to return Goal to Elysium and "unselfishly" earning him a complimentary admission ticket to the golden city (my words).Deponia has a lot to like. The first thing that is apparent about Deponia, is the cartoonish art-style.  Deponia is a literal world of junk, and everything in their society is constructed out what looks like the largest garbage dump known to man. Houses, buildings, everyday objects look like they were cobbled together out of repurposed items that were thrown away.The cartoon style also gives life to all of the characters.  Even the bit-part characters are uniquely designed and animated. Each one has their own personality, and backstory, which isn't told through a lot of needless and awkward exposition.  This also highlights the smart and clever writing. Through a few well-placed sentences, you can already grasp who the individual characters are.  I truly got the sense that this game could have been its own animated comedy series on television, and it would have held up.  While the cartoon comedy provides a lot of this games positives, there are a few downsides to this game.  Let's start with the puzzles.  The cartoonish nature of the game requires you to think as if you were in a cartoon environment. Which means that puzzles are deceptively easy, in that you have to think in very sideways terms, where most people will take a more literal approach.  For example, you are given instructions on how to assume a certain sitting pose to go into a meditative trance.  One of those instructions is to sit and place your left leg behind your head. When you get the place where you have to meditate, there is no place, or option to manipulate the character into the proper position. That is, until you take the leg from a skeleton, and place it behind you.  Many of the solutions will leave you groaning in both laughter, and frustration.Next are the mini-games.  There are a few of these sprinkled about in the game, but they have little to no explanation as to how they work, or how to achieve a solvable state. This will leave you scratching your head for hours, while you struggle to derive some kind of meaning of the game from the few, or lack or clues as to how they work.  Fortunately, the developers left an option to skip these mini-games, if you wish.Despite these flaws, I still think Deponia is worth its price-point.  It is funny, well-written, leaves room open for its sequels.  If you like these kinds of games, definitely give it a try. However, buy the bundle pack and stretch your money a little further.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Long, uninteresting, unintelligent dialogs, confusing and illogical puzzles, and a boring set of characters makes me never want to finish this game.Spoiler alert! The solution to one of the puzzles is to put two socks in a pot of boiling water. You use a fork to get them out, the fork disappears and you are left with only one sock. What!? I just put two socks in the pot and one of them disappears. I thought there was a bug in the game so I restarted and replayed everything up to the boiling water puzzle. Looking at the walkthrough revealed that there is a third sock under the pillow in the bed. Sigh!Oh, and the tutorial is the longest, most annoying, over explained, not funny at all tutorial for a game that doesn't need a tutorial.Deponia tries very hard to be Monkey Island. Even the voice of the protagonist sounds like Guybrush. Compared to Monkey Island, Deponia does not have the same finesse. You will never laugh out loud, or be surprised by the puzzles or enjoy the dialogue. The characters you meet feel very one dimensional and unintelligent. They lack the depth the characters of Monkey Island have. In my eyes, this game doesn't add anything new to the adventure genre, and it certainly isn't Monkey Island.

												It is a nice game with decent graphics and funny story, and I have even played and finished it at my friends computer when it was originally released, but sadly there there are some (randomly appearing) blocking bugs which makes the game unfinishable (from time to time). And as I rememeber, some of these bugs were there even when the game was originaly released, which was more than year ago. And gues what - they are still there (and if somebody is interested what is the problem is /this time/: there is no way to leave radio operator tower when he is overwhelmed by all the incomming comunications).So if you are willing to try to avoid these bugs (and possibly (re)play the game from the beginning for several times during the process), then go ahead and buy it, it is a GREAT funny game. You may even be so lucky that you will not encounter any of the bugs :)For everyone else - stay clear of it, you will get frustrated from triing to avoid these bugs...

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												An interesting little game that is let down by serious performance issues.While the art style and story were interesting enough to keep me playing, more than once I hit game-stopping bugs that forced me to kill the game from the task manager. The worst one halted progress during the final moments of the game, and when the game re-booted and allowed me to proceed all audio was cut out, leaving the closing scenes of the game to play out in silence.All of that could have been forgiven if the game wasn't so incredibly sluggish. When changing between areas it takes a few more seconds for anything to be able to intractable. So skipping around the town goes from being quick and painless to forehead vs. keyboard frustrating.If they can fix the loading and the bugs it'd be worth a look at, but in its current state your time would be better spent elsewhere.

content:
Posted: March 28
												The puzzles are made so open endedly that the game feels long and you don't know what steps you are supposed to take when trying to progress. It is a kind of game where you will be checking every single edge of the region and it feels like nothing you are trying is working. This game is almost impossible to completee if you do not have a walkthrough guiding you through some puzzles that just don't make logical sence.The most fatal problem is how badly the puzzles are placed through regions. When you are doing one of the puzzles you have to remember every detail or every screen you've been on previously or you won't know that you are supposed to back track and pick something up that you didn't even know was there. This reason to me is because all the items that you can interact ith are just blended into all the other eye junk. Trust me when I say this game has a lot of eye junk that will make the thing that will solve you puzzle almost invisible. There are no clues what so ever through the game the tell you how you are supposed to complete a puzzle, or how you are supposed to even go about completeing that puzzle.Bad puzzle design, if you do play you need a walkthrough open all the time. Puzzle games that REQUIRE walkthroughs for a player to feel like that are progressing are bad puzzle games.

To get 2 of the same colored socks you need to mix 3 random colored socks into a pot of boiling water, add soap and stir with a fork. Randumb game. Puzzles make zero sense with solutions being found by endless trial and error or referencing a walkthrough, over and over and over again. Main character is whiny and obnoxious. Scenery is decent but character animations look poor and dated. Humor is flat and obnoxious. They occasionally try to get people into the series by dropping this title as low as $0.99, so if you want to try it wait for the deep discount, but dont expect much.

												The game mechanics are solid, the animation is good. Music and sound is nice at first but gets boring and repetitive, outright annoying pretty quick. This is the kind of character who is proud of being an alcoholic ropist racist who sells Heroin to children (dramatization, only part of this is in the actual game, namely the rope and racism). Hey and I'm not one of these forking annoying SJWs either. Not all all, bro. This game just made me cringe and cringe and cringe and cringe and cringe so many times that I couldn't bring myself to start it up again.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												"Blech, Gnats♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; - RufusI got Deponia in a bundle including 4 other games, so I got my moneys worth out of it. That said, $1 isn't a lot to throw away. Deponia is NOT worth $20.It's a short, shallow post-apocalyptic world with no real attempt at world building (which is sad as the espresso machine showed that it could have had potential), with an unlikable main character (Being by design doesn't make it any better), puzzles that require out of game knowledge (Not everyone has heard of phosphorescence), and a pretentious end of act cutscenes that aren't adding anything to the narrative. Since they've been compared to LucasArts in the description, I feel I should say that this wouldn't even be Act 1 of a Monkey Island game.Rufus is the perfect mascot for this franchise - A self centered egotist who thinks they're a lot cleverer than they are.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												I have a very, very, very difficult time understanding the appeal of this game. I adore point and click adventures, but Jesus Christ, I couldn't even play this.I had to turn off the speech volume within a few minutes because I found the voice acting so utterly abrasive and obnoxious.Half of the humor seems like it was written by a six-year old. I don't recall the lines exactly, but things like "The clown of anaesthetics. Heh heh. Clowns!" and "You've never been a big help. You know, a big help. A BIG HELP. Heh heh. Because you're small." Honestly? Does the writer work at Hot Topic making buttons and t-shirts as their other job?Everyone despises the main character, Rufus, and for good reason. He's a complete tool and just irritating to play as.Usually I can get past things like that if the game itself is enjoyable, but it's ALSO disappointing. I can't believe this game has such positive feedback.I enjoy ridiculous and quirky, not asinine and witless. I can guarantee whoever wrote this, did so while wearing a fedora.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Pros:+Light-hearted game that makes lots of attempts at humor (some of them successful), especially in the dialog+Interesting setting and a likable main characterCons:-Pacing of the story is very poor. The story moves forward in a very jerky way with 30 second cutscenes of story followed by long, tedious bouts of point-and-click puzzle solving full of very contrived quests which are barely related to the story. (For example: To advance the story by one small increment, you've got to collect these six things. Oh, and each one will have some asinine obstacle blocking your ability to get it.) By the end of each of these game segments I was positively starved for some kind of progress in the story and on the verge of quitting. The story is interesting, but it moves at a snail's pace. It's super-annoying to play for an hour without getting so much as a crumb of story progress. This made the game feel long and dull to me.-I found several of the puzzles to be confusing rather than challenging. In a couple of cases I got the solution through random trial and error before actually understanding what the puzzle was I was supposed to be solving.-The story is completely unresolved, and all you get in the end is a "to be continued" ending.

number of helpful: 6 of 16 people (38%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												OK.... this is a NO review...I always try to be supportive of even the crappiest game, but this.... is... a bit too much crap for my taste.Before reading, please, if you are a huge fan of Daedalic games, you might find this review offensive.Actually, you WILL find this offensive.Do not read.I warned you.First of all, the MC.GAWD the only reason I ended this game was because I was too anal not to finish. I had lots and LOTS of AFK moments to cool down JUST BECAUSE of the MC. I'd rather play a total villain than this sad excuse for an anti-hero.I even turned off the audio because I hated listening to his dialogues, and yes, I also skipped through all.Next, the NPCs.Seriously, they are just as bad... except for 2 who were ridiculously harassed by the MC. I actually like these 2 and wonder, if the character designers are actually capable of creating these 2 great characters, then why is the MC such a crap??????You have anti-heroes, and you have jerks. I don't see any of the first in this game.Plot was OK. The world setting reminded me of the Japanese manga GUNM : Battle Angel Alita.Graphics are good. A good reminiscence of Monkey Island and Gabriel Knight (the 2D animation versions).Soundtrack.... no idea. I was so irritated by the MC's dialogue etc then I turned off the audio completely except when I needed it to solve puzzles. Even then I didn't register it into mind.Puzzle.The puzzles are FRUSTRATING and does not make sense. Yes, it's a fantasy world which isn't logical in the first place, but  unfortunately for puzzles, you do need logic. Fantasy world or not.The order does not make sense. I know what to do, and IMO it doesn't effect the game whatsoever if we mix up the orders anyway. But nooooooo..... we miss a step, we can't move on.I purchased a LOT of Daedalic games in a shopping binge because I was desperate for a good point-click game.Played 3, finished 2, and not even thinking about finishing the 3rd despite my anal-ness.Not even thinking about starting the other ones, and will re-fund if possible.If re-fund not possible, I might play the remaining games just to humor the money I spent, which is NOT happening anytime soon.If you're an avid collector of point-click games no matter what review, then go ahead and give this a try, though I do recommend... HIGHLY recommend that you purchase this only on a big sale.If you're looking for a good gaming time, move along. This is one game you can totally live without.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												It's quite surprising for me that there will be 4th part of Deponia soon, it shows that title is most successful one in Daedalic portfolio. To be honest, I have no idea why.Still Daedalic is very productive company and while some teams like Pendulo are just vanished in time and others like WadjetEye are just too old-school for modern common player there are plenty of adventure games from german devs.But Deponia definitely isn't one of the best.And it is not becase of many reasons:* you know, when you put your game into some irrational setting (just like scrapyard-city in the middle of the nowhere), you can afford any kind of "logic" you even may come up with. So you can force players to be wounded by chile pepper or hold with you unconsious parrot almost all the time and tell them that, guys, we are in the cartoon after all, but it is not something of a good taste and it is not mark of good game designer work* another problem is that game breaks its own rules. You need to use fork to take out socks from boiled water but you don't haveto have one to obtain sponge from same place* humor is german-specific and here it is SO german-specific* main character deserves terrible death - he is ugliest main persona since... I don't know. Since original sin* there are plenty of recorded phrases but quantity definitely does not transform into quality. Different interactions can have same reaction from protagonist. Rufus is very talkable one, but his blabla-ing is as annoying as he is. Prepare to listen silly stories about every your hot-spot click. Unfortunately there is no much useful information in themSo I'd like to recommend to play any other adventure, even from Daedalic. Why don't you choose A New Beginning for example?And, dear Daedalic, could you please deal with animation? While overall graphic style is just great characters' speech with 2 drawn frames per sentence can frighten expierenced screamer-lovers.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												This game is so "funny" I can't stand it.  Not quite "ha ha" or "heh" funny ... more like "your screaming 9 year old nephew wrote the dialog while eating a 50 lb bag of cotton candy and leaving sticky fingerprints all over your screen and spilling soda in your keyboard, and maybe someday we'll look back at this and laugh".I was excited for this game given the obviously high art quality and ratings, but I made it through the tutorial and first scene and could stomach no more.  As some people have mentioned, the puzzles were harder than many other contemporary adventure games, but they were far from impossible and roughly on-par with the old classics.  The only positive thing I can say about the gameplay is that the solutions to the puzzles were actually amusing, and require you to behave like the horrible person the protagonist is trying to be.Maybe I'll take a deep breath and try again soon.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												Storyline moves very VERY slow because of the puzzles, which give you almost no clues or help, and many were solved by sheer luck. (though the game DOES allow you to skip the puzzles if they are too hard, which is nice, i guess?) Came to find that the story is very unfinished, and there are four games, rnaging from twenty to thirty bucks each, and it's definitely not worth ~$90 to find out the ending. I would also not recommend the trilogy pack, as it is still missing the last part of the game, which costs another $30. Pros:- Game was very interesting visually- Occasionally humorous- Puzzles were challenging, and when done right were enjoyable- Story is very interesting and makes you want to know more about the world of the game, and its historyCons:- You never get answers to half the questions you have about the game or its characters- Main character is dislikable as hell, making you wonder why you're even bothering to assist him- Most parts of the game give you NO clue how to progress, (minigames aside, spending 15 minutes trying to figure out where to click is irritating enough) - Story was very short, when all's said and done, but moves extremely slowly, so what would take 1hr to replay takes 6 or 7 the first time around

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												This game isn't garbage, but I still felt the need to get my $3 refund for it. I thought I'd grab it on sale because the story and gameplay looked lighthearted and funny, but I really just found it to be waste of my time that didn't even make me smile once. It is definitely quirky and the characters have an overly sarcastic sense of humor, so I can see how some people may find it funny (I guess). The gameplay is absurd and you'll find yourself just clicking everywhere on the screen to try and figure out what the hell you're supposed to do next. A lot of what you have to do to progress makes no sense because of how whacky the game is as a whole. You'll have about as much luck as a 6 year old when trying to figure it out. Bottom line is, don't buy this game if you won't be satisfied with a very simple point & click adventure. The gameplay is definitely lacking and the story really isn't that good by any means either imo. If you do like basic point & click games, maybe you'll like it. But I still can't see how anyone finds this game that great. It's not terrible, but who wants to waste their time with that?

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												I see a lot of people seem to like this game, but I'm kinda starting to hate it. I'd say this is one of the worst quests I've ever played. Although the design is pretty nice, I particularly love the soundtrack and the way the characters are drawn but...1. The protagonist himself is DISUGSTING. He's a typical loser with stupid jokes and no interests at all except for getting stuff for free and without any effort. Why would anyone ever want to live his life? 2. The quests. They don't have any logic and you have to do ugly things too often. But that could have been okay if... there was any logic. It's close to impossible to crack some puzzles. I failed to solve the puzzle with the pigeons simply because I guess I clicked on the wrong button and I can't access the puzzle anymore. I read 3 or 4 walkthroughs and none of them helped. This is the first time a quest made me so frustrated. I'll give the game 2/10. It's really not worth trying. The night of the rabbit that I bought the same day is much much better.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												You want a nice, logical, point and click adventure game where you don't need a guide to finish it?Then look elsewhere.If you're a masochist who loves clicking everything on everything else and can stand long periods of boredom and doing nothing productive, then by all means, get this game.  It's the same problem that plagued the genre in the 1980's and 90's, and still found it's way into this game in 2012.  It's ridiculous.  I thought we were past crap like this these days.I got this game for dirt cheap as part of some Humble Bundle.  And I still feel like I was cheated.  Old school traditional style point and click adventure games like this, with maybe one or two exceptions, need to freaking die as a genre.

												Personally i really like Point and Click adventures since Monkey Island and especially since "Broken Sword" (Baphomets Fluch) so if you don't like P&C games at all this recommendation could be wrong for you.Deponia (1st of 3 planned parts) is a game where you play as Rufus, a outsider who still lives at his ex-girlfriend in Deponia (a planet full of garbage which seems to be our earth in future) and dreams about a (flying city) called Elysium which (indeed exist) but not everyone has acces to it. His life goal is to escape from Deponia so the first what you do is another attempt to get there which goes not totally wrong. Instead, you bring "Goal" (a girl from Elysium) to Deponia and totally fall in love with her. But... she's unconscious. In Part 1 you mostly try to awake her which seems not that easy.The jokes and situations in which Rufus gets are really funny and very strange.Open End cause of part 2 ofc. 8/10

content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												Daedalic Entertainment, once called “Lucasarts from Germany“ by the GameStar magazine, invites the players into a fantastic comedy adventure that revolves around a crazy love story of Rufus and Goal. In Deponia, the world has degenerated into a vast garbage dump, in which the crotchety Rufus ekes out his sorry existence. He is part of the lowest social class, doomed to live his life in literal mountains of trash. He hopes for an opportunity to get into the world of the rich, who live in a floating city high above the clouds. Fate seems to smile on the snotty good-for-nothing when one day the attractive lady named Goal from the higher sector plummets into one of the trash heaps. Rufus decides to help the young woman out by taking her back to her husband. When he notices that Goal's husband is a dead ringer for himself, he hatches a diabolical scheme to gain access to the upper world. However, things don't work out quite as planned, since he has feelings for the beauty which limits his usual unscrupulousness. Help Rufus, the poor boy from the junkyard, to win over the girl from heaven. Only with this rich girl from his dreams he might be able to escape Deponia and, unexpectedly, to save the planet.

A woman from another planet falls from the sky and the town hall is filled with the town's men negotiating who gets to 'keep' her. Not to mention such hilarious jokes as a non-passing trans-woman secretary; the main character's irritation at being misidentified as 'Sugarpuff;' and the ex-girlfriend snapping at the main character that she's not going to let him spike her drink with a tranquilizer again. No thanks.

Finally the game ends too much with a hint for a sequel, which I do not appreciate as a serious business model that respects gamers (at least adventures aren't too expensive these days).That and the above puzzle flaws give the game an unpolished character. But that 's all I want to criticize here.Really good game overall, had a lot of laughs.8/10

Posted: May 9, 2014
												This won't be a glowing review. I'll recommend it, but with reservations. If it's on sale for $3.50 or less and you want an interesting, fairly unique story, along with some good adventure game puzzles, then it's a good buy. For any more than that, don't waste your time.So, I'm not an adventure game kinda guy. I didn't like Myst at all, and never got around to many other point-and-click's. A lot felt like pixel hunting and didn't have very logical puzzle solutions. There's very few of those moments in Deponia. Holding the spacebar will reveal all the available hotspots, and many of the solutions make sense. Naturally some seem a little over-complicated, but given the items you're allowed to use they make more sense.The story is interesting, and I found it quite unique. It doesn't give you any agency to change outcomes, but the dialogue driving it is, for the most part, witty and funny.The music is awesome and indeed, the chorus guys rule.Now the bad.This game is horribly, horribly unoptimized. I understand that a few players haven't had any issues, but I spent a lot of time reading the forums and I'm certain that I had every issue mentioned by anyone, and at least one that I didn't see mentioned.The game chugs. I'm not certain why it drops performance so bad, but it does. At first, I thought the animations just had low framerates (The walking animations are fine, as well as the movies by the way. I'm talking about the mouse cursor and inventory screen animations), but at one point there was a sound effect happening in the background at a regular interval. When I pulled up my inventory, or when I pressed spacebar to reveal the hot-spots, the sound effect slowed down by at least half. The game seems to run at around 30fps normally, but was dropping to as low as 5fps during these particular times. I really don't know why a point-and-click should be so resource intensive on a machine that can comfortably run AAA games at high settings.Also, there are a few bugs with not being able to hit certain hotspots at certain times. Trying to exit the listening post is an example. There are workarounds such as talking to the guy who's up there first, but pressing spacebar reveals the exit arrow as an option, so I see no reason it shouldn't be one immediately.The minecart minigame with the correct solution would not allow me to progress. Thankfully they allow you to skip it. Still, that seems like an awful cop-out.One more, that I didn't see anyone ask about, is that the dialogue options would occasionally appear partially above the frame they're enclosed in, thereby obscuring some of the options. Or the options would appear partially below the frame, and therefore partially off-screen thereby rendering some options un-clickable. Cycling through the dialogue options usually fixed the problem. Again, the problem should not exist in the first place.Don't be fooled by the settings, changing them changed nothing about how the game reacted on my machine. Texture compression, weather effects, anything, they all ran exactly the same.Don't be fooled by the demo. The demo ran fine on my machine, full framerates and no dialogue, hotspot, or puzzle issues at all. These were definitely not indicative of the state of the full game.To wrap things up, the game has an interesting story, I like the art style, and it's mostly funny. But, those developers did a terrible job with their QA. Don't buy the game if it's not on sale.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												I've always enjoyed adventure puzzles game since I was younger. This is my grown up version of Freddi Fish or Spy Fox. That being said this is the first Daedalic Entertainment game I've played. And from other reviews... I hope the others are better. I was disappointed with couple things. The biggest being the bugs surrounding important plot actions. If certain actions are not taken appropriately (i.e. a conversation option is skipped) it may have an impact on continuing in game. Also the story was a little lacking... I'm in for not everything having a happy ending but... you always hope the time you put into a game rewards you with some fulfillment. Overall, I enjoyed this game. I wouldn't necessarily recommend to a friend. But I loved the witty humor and the artistic direction. Despite the bugs, it worked for me. Hopefully Daedalic releases some patches in the future to improve the gameplay.

Posted: April 24, 2014
												This game has by far one of the best stories I've ever seen in a game. Not only is it comical and puzzling at the same time, but Rufus is so relatable (To me anyway). With all of his escapades, and disasters associated with him the community doesn't take a liking to him... well, nobody really takes a liking to him. But! 												What can I say? My first adventure game I completed was Leisure Suit Larry in the Land of Lounge Lizards in late 80's, and I have been fan of adventure game genre ever since. I had quite high expectations of this game. It looks nice, and the setting is interesting. However, the puzzles... They are not puzzles. They are tedious combinatorial work with little or no logic. A review in Metacritic pointed to walkthrough to see what is wrong with this game and now I do the same. See how to make espresso! The solution to this single operation... it's 6 freaking pages long, containing about 200 steps, and there are literally tens of steps that do not make sense in any way. The puzzles really get in the way of the story. That's it. I feel like a monkey who is supposed to guess what the designers had in mind. I don't think it's fun at all.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												While I did enjoy this game for its lovely art style and its classic 90s era take on the adventure genre, I can only recommend this first entry in the series with some reservations.  The dystopian setting of the titular Deponia is a literal trash heap orbited by the idyllic Elysium (not to be confused with the blockbuster movie of the same name, with the same plot).  The cartooniness dulls the edge of the grim setting, but there's still some hearty meat to it.  This first entry explores much of what there is worth exploring, and the ending feels solid enough that you can easily leave it there without further sequels.However, throughout the game the central character Rufus becomes more and more insufferable.  He's endearing at first, but near the end of the game it starts to become exhausting.  For this first entry, it's not quite a deal breaker.  But by the start of the sequel, he gets to the point of being completely intolerable.  While it's obvious they're trying to channel Guybrush Threepwood, it crosses some hard to define line at some point and he becomes so grating you just can't help but turn it off.

Posted: July 12, 2015
												Deponia is a Point & Click game and the first part of a trilogy, preceding Chaos on Deponia and Goodbye Deponia.The game takes place on the planet Deponia, a real discharge on a large scale. At a distance floats a paradisiac platform, Elysium, reserved for rich people and inaccessible for the inhabitants of Deponia. We control Rufus, a clumsy character with an outsize ego, which loathes the household and working, and wishes only a thing: leave Deponia for Elysium. During an attempt to leave Deponia, Rufus meets Goal, a young inhabitant of Elysium who's here by mistake. He thus decides to return her at home, while hoping to be able to take advantage of it to join Elysium.All right, the scenario is not very original, we stay in the classic pattern of a prince who has to save the princess. But the universe is very nice, rather funny, both by the mind of the characters and by the nonsense of some situations. The gameplay is simple, we collect objects, then we combine them with other objects in the inventory to interact with the elements of the screen. Furthermore, by pressing on the space bar, we can locate at once the elements which we can interact, even if it is never very complicated to find them.Deponia is reminiscent of one of the pillars of the Point and Click, one of my favorite games: Monkey Island. Even if this latter remains much better, we do not remain indifferent to Deponia, to its cartoon animations, its colored universe, its musics and sound effects. Deponia should take you till 10 hours of game to end it. At the end of the game, you unlock the mode Droggeljug, completely useless, which replace all the names and conversations by the word "Droggeljug". But it's fun! :)

Posted: July 14, 2015
												It was an okay game. Some parts were difficult to get through as this game was sexist, homophobic, and transphobic. The main character is the "typical" egotistic, lazy, and dirty minded male. The plot is focus on Rufus attempting to leave Deponia, lugging around an unconscious damsel in distress, and then switching out her BRAIN IMPLANT for his benefit. Worst of all her name is GOAL! Really, that is her name!  Point and click adventures are a genre I enjoy, and it was sad to see such a difference in gaming experience between this and Edna & Harvey: Harvey's New Eyes. The puzzles themselves were enjoyable and there were moments of humor in good taste. Overall, I would not have bought this game knowing what it truly was, and ignored the very positive reviews. If you like a game that has sexism woven throughout, then this is a game you most likely will enjoy!

Posted: July 17, 2015
												Good Story.Forgive me getting through the story by looking guides all the way. However, this way still gives me a feeling like watching a 8/10 or higher rate movie.

Posted: July 30, 2015
												Deponia is a point and click adventure puzzle game about a man named Rufus who lives on a "Planet" entirely covered in garbage. (I say Planet with quotations simply because the characters state it's on a planet different form a city called Elysium, located high in the sky, presumably in orbit, even if that doesn't work at all). It's set in the future of our time so you could say it fits into Sci-Fi aswell.Either way, Rufus wants to get to Elysium and he's... well he's rather mad, but he has the brains to get out of any situation, including the situation where he's on Deponia, a place he hates more than anybody else.The game takes... well about as long as it's taken to beat it, but unfortunately like all games in the same genre, once you play it, it takes basically 30 minutes tops to beat it again, knowing all the information, even if that's good for a few laughs.When you play this game, in order to beat some part you REALLY gotta think with conventional logic or even like a smart person and I sometimes fail at that, requiring a walkthrough to figure out what to do with some things.The game has alot of tongue-in-cheek humor bits, and even some normal bits of humor. The art style is very nice with great animations, although unfortunately the lip-syncing is sometimes a bit off, like in the start of the game, it's not too big of a deal.The music is also great but if you get stuck, turn it off or you'll hear it again and again. There's not really too much music, variation for music would've helped somewhat. The game has cats at one point and they're miserably adorable.The puzzles are challenging, but ofcourse it's the main reason as to why it takes 30-40 minutes to beat it given all the puzzle answers are given to you.The story is very engaging though, it's easily the best part of this game. I love Rufus' character, the other characters are just as great, all of them very well voiced and even to say the least, they are even interesting people... when looking at main character such as Gizmo, Rufus, Wenzel, etc.I personally loved playing this game start to finished and even after all this time, I still have the puzzles all memorized to heart... mostly.Droggeljug mode is a special mode that makes it extremely difficult if you don't remember dialogue options, or even know how to skip things as literally every word of text and even dialogue is replaced with the word Droggeljug. Just one of them for text, however this would've been nice for dialogue too as it doesn't follow the same thing, causing Droggeljug mode to be deeply irritating. It could be changed by simply having one word per dialogue option instead of it being word for word replacement.Altogether, the game gets an 8/10. It's great fun, has a splendid atmoshpere, world and story, and the characters are nice too.It would score a 10/10 but Droggeljug mode being really annoying as the word that characters say have no variation, it's just one sound clip looped over and over per character, it detracts from it a fair amount in addition to the fact that many items used on something results in the exact same reaction from Rufus in contexts that don't really make any sense for it, and also if the music had some variation, as it will eventually lose it's value as you get stuck (if you're like me, you WILL get stuck at least once) and hear it for many loops of it.

Posted: October 30, 2015
												Most gamers would probably not be bothered by the content but I can't recommend this game to anyone that's sensitive to oppressive themes. Outside of the offensive content, the game is mediocre overall but possibly worth playing for fans of the genre.The good: The art is beautiful, the animation is great, the music is apt, and the voice acting is solid. These things are so good that I continued to play it despite feeling completely alienated by the story. The puzzles are thoroughly uninspired and lacking logical progression. I found myself just trying random things on many occasions.The mediocre: It doesn't bring anything new to the genre in terms of mechanics. The few non-offensive jokes and cultural references fell flat for me. The original german language is occasionally conspicuous in the voiceovers and subtitles.The bad: The writing was absolutely offensive to me from the outset. The main character, Rufus, is deeply misogynistic, disrespectful, and downright unlikable. But the offensiveness goes beyond rufus being a repulsive character, it's pervasive to almost every element of the game and betrays a deep bias in the writers and creators. The characters are almost entirely men, and the few that aren't are subject to intense scrutiny or objectification. Femininity is downright mocked. There is overt transmisogyny. There aren't any characters of color. Oppressive themes are used throughout as a crutch for weak and unoriginal writing. I certainly don't expect every game to be a paragon of feminism but this game is embarrasing.
