Posted: February 2, 2014
												Deponia is a adventure game of the type I like the most. Challenging puzzles, cartoony 2D-graphics, no action elemements and a good humorous story.The best aspect of the game is probably the creative andsometimes quite challenging puzzles. In some adventure games the solution to a puzzle is almost immediately obvious because there are so few possible things to try. In Deponia trial and error is not a quick and easy approach, since there are many objects and lots of things to interact with. In particular in the first part of the game the puzzles require a bit of out of the box thinking without being unfair. Puzzles are also fairly varied and always feel like a natural part of the game rather than tacked on. My only complaint in this department is that the very end of the game is a bit anticlimactic in terms of puzzle difficulty.The story is humorous and entertaining with unique character. The humour doesn't always work, but there are moments of brilliance, and it worked often enough to keep me entertained throughout. The ending is a bit disappointing but it does leave things at an appropriate starting point for the sequel.The cartoony graphics are entirely appropriate given the general tone of the game and are high quality and quite distinctive. Characters each have their own unique appearance and do not look generic at all like they do in too many games.Voice acting is above average but not exceeptional. The music has a unique style that is very appropriate given the particular setting and is quite appealing too.All in all this is a highly recommended adventure game if you like pure point and click adventures with challenging puzzles and a healthy dose of humour.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												Review time for Deponia.Story- Deponia is a world of trash... literally. The people live in trash on top of mountains of trash making a living from trash. But for a brash, lazy, young Rufus, he wanted more. So in his latest hair-brained scheme to escape to Elesium, he saves a a damsel in distress from a militant group and finds himself mixed in a conspiracy that will affect everyone on Deponia. The story is a good bit of comedy in the vein of Lucas Arts "The Curse of Monkey Island" with memorable characters and involving plot twists. The world in the story is also very imaginative and filled with a lot of potetial for exploration. A+Graphics- Those who are familiar with "The Curse of Monkey Island" may see a lot of similarities in art style. It does show that many of the developers and artist were fans of Lucas Arts. But dispite similarities, this game is a whole new beast and completely original in character design and world creation and is every well done. The cutscenes are also very well done and is like looking at a cartoon television show. ASound- The voice acting in this game is spot on in terms of delivery, though the lip-sync can be terribly off which was a little bit destracting, but not unforgivable. As for the music... I LOVE THE MUSIC! There is a very good mix of ballads, a touch of hip-hop and just fun altogether. A+Gameplay- Simple, straight forward point and click interface with combining items for more items. If you've played old school adventure games before then it is very familiar territory. There is also a fair amount of challenges and puzzles that will keep you puzzled but if your stuck, there is an option to skip it. BOverall- A fantasic throw back for fans of old style P.O.C. games with a fantastic story, great characters and music that should not be missed. Highly recomended. A

												The puzzles are challenging, forcing you to adopt a non-traditional form of logic to solve them. The main character is so self-centered, he's delusional. Most importantly, the story is quite amusing and well written. The jokes range from cartoon slapstick to innuendo to bizzarre WTF situations. It tells the story of eternal screwup and egomaniac Rufus and his efforts to escape the garbage-filled planet he lives on to reach a floating city, Elysium.All in all, the game is well paced, funny, and the right mix of challenging and logical. Posted: March 14, 2016
												Deponia is literally a dump that Rufus is desperate to leave at the expensive of his friends and his ex, for reasons that are not immediatley apparent. This pretty much makes him a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥bag, but once past this initial premise, Deponia provides a fun point and click ride.Its full of humour aimed in all directions, jibes at characters, adventure game tropes and even at the player trying all combos to progress, it genuinely puts a smile on your face.The puzzles are well paced, starting in confined areas and expanding the world as you go. Two thumbs up from me..

Posted: March 9, 2016
Overall:  It's a good point and click adventure.  I absolutely recommend if it's on sale.  Whether you want to pay full price is up to how much of a point and click enthusiast you are.Story: Slow start, but I was hooked the moment Rufus tormented Toni in her shop.  Many point and click adventures have degrees of moon logic where a nonsensical combination of items and actions somehow solves the problem, but Deponia makes it somehow seem almost rational in hindsight.  Rufus often made me simultaneously gasp in horror and laugh at some of the stunts he pulled on his fellow Deponians.Gameplay:  It has a moderate amount of pixel hunting.  Some of the scenes are extremely cluttered and can make finding the one thing needed difficult.  The majority of puzzles aren't terribly hard to figure out, though some of them require patient trial and error or a quick google search.

Posted: October 27, 2015
												Buyer beware, this game might not work on your computer. I have a very up to date desktop system and the game still refused to start. It kept having errors either saying the file was corrupted or didn't exist no matter how many times I installed it. I read somewhere that changes to the visual settings help... Still said corrupted. I read that it only works on older systems for some reason, tried it on an old laptop, still didn't work. Did more research which said the game needed a missing DLL file. Another source said it was an error in DirectX....After many unsuccessful attempts to get the game just to start, I asked for a refund which was granted almost immediately by steam. I think Daedalic recently released a patch for Deponia, but I don't believe it resolves any startup issues. Sadly, I can't say how the actual game is because I never got to play it. That's way more effort than anyone should ever have to put into installing a simple point & click game.  This was my experience, you might not have any problems. I have friends with older systems who have played Deponia without issue. I'm leaving a negative review so that other people will be aware that Deponia has this game-breaking glitch upon startup. I recommend testing the game out as soon as possible after purchase so if you have similar problems, you'll still be in Steam's timeframe for a refund.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												While Telltale have, to much acclaim, been moving the adventure genre in a new, more serious, direction, Daedalic have been working away at old school point and click games, focusing on visual style, witty writing and great characterisation. Deponia places you in the shoes of Rufus, a rather arrogant, unlikable and hilariously callous protagonist, as he attempts to escape his dull life on the titular garbage planet. Along the way players will take blood from a mechanical bull, gas a parrot, contend with cross dressing receptionists and participate in the ancient and arcane ritual of espresso-making. Deponia is clearly a game in the tradition of Monkey Island series, with a manic and  oddball approach to its world building. It's also a worthy sucessor to those games, and well worth a look.

Posted: July 12, 2015
												Deponia is a Point & Click game and the first part of a trilogy, preceding Chaos on Deponia and Goodbye Deponia.The game takes place on the planet Deponia, a real discharge on a large scale. At a distance floats a paradisiac platform, Elysium, reserved for rich people and inaccessible for the inhabitants of Deponia. We control Rufus, a clumsy character with an outsize ego, which loathes the household and working, and wishes only a thing: leave Deponia for Elysium. During an attempt to leave Deponia, Rufus meets Goal, a young inhabitant of Elysium who's here by mistake. He thus decides to return her at home, while hoping to be able to take advantage of it to join Elysium.All right, the scenario is not very original, we stay in the classic pattern of a prince who has to save the princess. But the universe is very nice, rather funny, both by the mind of the characters and by the nonsense of some situations. The gameplay is simple, we collect objects, then we combine them with other objects in the inventory to interact with the elements of the screen. Furthermore, by pressing on the space bar, we can locate at once the elements which we can interact, even if it is never very complicated to find them.Deponia is reminiscent of one of the pillars of the Point and Click, one of my favorite games: Monkey Island. Even if this latter remains much better, we do not remain indifferent to Deponia, to its cartoon animations, its colored universe, its musics and sound effects. Deponia should take you till 10 hours of game to end it. At the end of the game, you unlock the mode Droggeljug, completely useless, which replace all the names and conversations by the word "Droggeljug". But it's fun! :)

Posted: June 4, 2015
												Personally, I have never been a fan of point and click games, however, Deponia has entirely changed that. I originally batted about the idea of purchasing Deponia because the art style really appealed to me, but I was put off by the play style and the price. However, when it came on sale for £0.79 I snapped it up without a second thought, as, even if I were only to use it for artistic reference, I knew I wouldn’t regret spending that on it. It is probably the best thing I’ve ever bought for under a pound. Immediately, I was hooked. It is fun and immersive, and, though it appears to have some childish tones, the dialogue and extremely well-developed characters provide many humorous moments and you start to see that it is rather adult in its comedic value. Then there’s the difficulty. I never imagined that a point and click adventure would prove so taxing! The hidden objects, the combinations required, the little puzzles and the specific orders required for the completion of tasks often left me scratching my head and, I will admit, if I hadn’t had the opportunity to glance at a walk through on the odd occasion, I doubt I would be anywhere near completing it right now (though I avoided using the guide as much as possible, of course). I’ve still not unlocked all of the achievements! I am not entirely sure whether it has a lot of replay value, but I know I will be coming back to it simply because I will miss the atmosphere and the quirky characters! And I will admit, though Rufus is an egocentric jerk and possibly one of the worst boyfriends in gaming history, he is very loveable and under it all, a real sweetheart.The only thing I can complain about with Deponia is the fact that it is too short, and the prices on the series are a bit high for my liking, but the moment the sequels come on sale I will be snapping them up! So yes, I whole-heartedly recommend this game. It is beautiful, the sound track is super funky, the characters are funny and unique and it does supply a good challenge to keep your mind occupied. Plus, my toothbrush ran away and hid in a dark corner, mocking me from the shadows, and I made coffee out of battery acid and gave it to a cat who licked stamps… What’s not to love? 10/10

Posted: May 15, 2015
												Click everything you seeDeponia is your standard point and click adventure game that lacks a soul just like German knock knock jokes. Fortunately, it's just funny and pretty enough to keep playing.STORY- Typical anti-hero doing typical anti-hero things on a garbage planet.GRAPHICS- The art style and animation is actually very appealing, one thing Daedalic Entertainment has had a strong point in.SOUNDTRACK- Something Daedalic Entertainment does not have a strong point in. (Except the intro, the intro is awesome)GAMEPLAY-    Pros-   You click stuff   The dialogue can be amusing   Deponia is a planet overflown with trash   Cons-   You click stuff. Like you literally end up clicking everything because you have no idea how you're supposed to get a certain task done. Then when you find the solution, you rage at the randomness of the solution.   The dialogue can be the opposite of amusing (Gotta love cultural barriers)   Everyone is an♥♥♥♥♥ Even you (Especially you). Almost all your conversations are with asses.   Late game puzzles are confusing as hell (well for me)   There is no replay value. (There is a mode post game where it changes all dialogue to druggelburg or something. Is that supposed to be funny?)CONCLUSION-It's an average point and click adventure game with an appealing art style as its main saving grace. Daedalic really had a chance to make this a great game due to such a unique world setting, but looks like they're all talk. Get it on sale if you have the urge for point and click adventures. However be warned, the sequels in this trilogy are complete♥♥♥♥♥♥

Posted: January 29, 2016
												I wanted to like this game. I really did. TL; DR If you like mindles click spam puzzle games that require zero logic, then I guess you should get it.The story is not too bad and the graphics are really nice.  .......but.What made me give a negative review is the puzzle solving mechanism which is just..horrible. 95% of the time there are absolutely no hints or clues about what you have to do next. You picked up some items because you cliked on everything that was clickable; tho using this items requires multiple spamming, usually just trying to use every item from your inventory on an object (only to find out neither of those are meant to be used and then doing the same on next object, etc.), or trying to connect all the items in your inventory together in hope you're going to craft something useful. And sometimes these crafted objects made absolutely zero sense.The walking and overall moving was very badly done and often very very annoying, and the jokes are just.. Not funny. I can see it tries hard to be funny but it's just not. Also the characters are one of the most annoying I have ever met in the game.I finished the game, but I had to keep the walktrough opened at all times because at most times I had zero idea about what to do next since there is absolutely no hints.I hope the other sequels are done better on this point.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												Deponia is a great point-and-click adventure game with really well-implemented puzzle mechanics. As you progress through the game, you will encounter puzzle-like situations that is so well-blended with the story it makes you feel like you're creating the next scenes, or like you're leading the story by solving these puzzles. The game's difficulty is also definitely fair, as you're often given clues on how to solve difficult puzzles if you look around the environment. Not to mention that the following results of your actions in the game are, more often than not, hilarious as hell (or at least I find wreaking havoc, destroying things and ruining people's day pretty damn comedic). But if not for the puzzles or comedy, I at least found the story very compelling (made me sat through the whole game in one day).Definitely would recommend this game, or even the whole trilogy, to anyone who wants a giggle or those who simply enjoy good puzzles and good story.

												One of the better adventure game series to come along in quite a while.  This series of games is basically the offspring of the old Lucasarts and Sierra adventure games (more the former than the latter).  It features slightly warped humor, interesting multi-step puzzles that [mostly] make sense once you put the pieces together, with cool cut scenes and an ongoing story line that will actually make you want to play the sequels. Posted: May 27, 2015
												I am not a fan of point-and-click games, but Deponia makes it just a an easy stress-free medium by being a point-and-click release. You hardly seem to notice that after you play the game for a while, because the flow of it is that smooth. The story itself isn't anything mind blowing, but it is captivating to make you go back until you find out what the future holds for Rufus. As for Rufus himself, there were times when I would get just downright annoyed by how much of an egocentric egomaniac he truly was, but he had me back on his side with his goofy humor. The rest of Deponia's inhabitants have their undoubtful charm, Lottie in particular. The cut-scenes are hilarious at times, the whole "science" and "philosophy" in game are completely absurd (along with their love counsel) and thus gut-busting. The graphics themselves are pleasant to the eye, even though most of them depict what essentially is a junkyard. They add to the absurdity of the game. In general, great game if you just want to relax and laugh a lot, without playing games that all give you the same feel of over-chewed gum. In terms of being a point-and-click game it convinced me to look more into these, maybe I'll find more of such gems.

Posted: January 10, 2014
												From the makers of ''The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav''. ''Deponia'' is a game developed and pubished by Daedalic Entertainment.Preface!Due to this game being ''story driven'', I am not going to go into mush detail or spoil anything major of the Story. The story centers around Rufus: a young, sarcastic, bold, lying, selfish man who wants to leave the junk town of Kovaq - a town Rufus has known for so long - and look for his, not-so known, father. Rufus believes his father abandoned him for the floating city of Elysium when Rufus was very young.And so, Rufus makes it his ultimate destiny to go to Elysium; to prove his own father that Rufus can go to Elysium.During Rufus Journey, he ends up meeting people and they end up helping him on his travel.The tone of the story is comedy mixed with seriousness. About 95% of the game is comedy while the small 5% is seriousness. I can't say in which part the game gets serious.The ending of the game, in a way, touched my heart. I can't say  in detail of what happened in the ending, but it got to do with all Rufus had done during his Jouney.I like Deponias' animation. The animation is hand drawn. The animation suits well with the comedic tone of the game.Deponia is a hard point-and-click game and is a lot more harder than ''The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav''.Items do not ''highlight'' when you hover over them with something else.There is no quest log... so... you are probably going to wander aimlessly around in the game and be like ''uhmm... what am I suppose do again?''.I recommend this game to people who wants a challengine Point-and-click game.Deponia gets an 8/10.

Posted: January 25, 2015
												This is a hard game to review.   It's a game with a strong storyline and some genuinely funny dialogue.  The puzzles occasionally lack much logic and can sometimes only be solved through guesswork (or by referring to a walkthrough) but this is a common problem with point-and-click adventure games and I would say that it's no worse than its peers in that regard.However, it's not a game that everyone will enjoy.    Whereas other adventure game characters like Guybrush Threepwood are hapless and inept, the protagonist of this game, Rufus, is rude, selfish, callous, sexist and egocentric.   This is a protagonist who you should probably not identify with or even sympathise with (although you probably will as you get drawn into the narrative)The humour is mostly derived from Rufus creating plans that go wrong and behaving in such a way as to cause misery and misfortune to those around them.   This is of course a well-established form of black comedy and I think that most people will be able to take it as it was intended.However, there are a number of jokes that contain elements that are as likely to cause offence and upset rather than amusement.   There are three main instances of this (from the entire trilogy):- One character is depicted in a very transphobic light- One character suffers through a racially demeaning situation (due to the protagonist)- One character is a paedophileThese are all intended as jokes and the author of the game has clarified that racially charged scene was not meant to convey a positive message about racism (the humour is derived from how awful the situation is) but it may still limit the ability of some people to enjoy the game.If you particularly enjoy point-and-click games and can tolerate the occasionally moment of humour in bad taste then you will enjoy this game.   If you are sensitive about racism, transphobia or sex crime then you may find that some jokes spoil your ability to enjoy the rest of the game.

												A fantastic adventure game, featuring some extremely intelligent riddles that require deep thinking. At the same time, it narrates a beautiful story, one that takes place in a setting very different than those of most adventure games. Recommended for everyone interested in the genre, It offers a classic, challenging gameplay, which should be enough to keep fans of the adventures games playing till they finish it. The controls and voice acting is top notch. The storyline is humerous and fun. However, the ending was a total buildup for the second installment. A tad dissapointing. There is about 8 - 15 hours of gameplay, depending how long it takes you to do the puzzles. At best the game is worth only $15. Seeing how you will most likely need all three installments for some closer, the total package could be worth $30 if you get about 10 hours of gameplay out of each installment. I will get the other installments when they go on sale.

Posted: October 26, 2014
												[Edit: The standalone game has now been patched as well. This means I can recommend the game, with the caveat of checking current special offers (vs The Complete Journey). Leaving the original review below since the bait-and-switch still DID occur.]Good game BUT a word of warning:Deponia and it's sequels are since september 2014 presumably abandonware. Instead of patching the remaining bugs of the separate games the developer/publisher Daedalic decided to release an all-in-one title called Deponia: The Complete Journey. It's a completely new separate title, not a 'pack' containing the previous games, so there is no way to upgrade from the standalone titles. It also does not create giftable versions of the titles you already own.If you are new to the game and want to buy and play Deponia (which is a terrific and fun Point-and-Click) get The Complete Journey.Personally I think this move is blatantly unfriendly to early adopters and existing customers and would probably not buy anything from Daedalic again, let alone this new all-in-one version.

Posted: October 27, 2015
												Buyer beware, this game might not work on your computer. I have a very up to date desktop system and the game still refused to start. It kept having errors either saying the file was corrupted or didn't exist no matter how many times I installed it. I read somewhere that changes to the visual settings help... Still said corrupted. I read that it only works on older systems for some reason, tried it on an old laptop, still didn't work. Did more research which said the game needed a missing DLL file. Another source said it was an error in DirectX....After many unsuccessful attempts to get the game just to start, I asked for a refund which was granted almost immediately by steam. I think Daedalic recently released a patch for Deponia, but I don't believe it resolves any startup issues. Sadly, I can't say how the actual game is because I never got to play it. That's way more effort than anyone should ever have to put into installing a simple point & click game.  This was my experience, you might not have any problems. I have friends with older systems who have played Deponia without issue. I'm leaving a negative review so that other people will be aware that Deponia has this game-breaking glitch upon startup. I recommend testing the game out as soon as possible after purchase so if you have similar problems, you'll still be in Steam's timeframe for a refund.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												You play as Rufus, who aspires to escape the junk world of Deponia to the utopia of Elysium. But his biggest obstacle? Himself. Rufus is an anti-hero. He is incompetent and somewhat of a scoundral (the latter becomes more apparent in the sequels). This differentiates Deponia from other adventure games. The player is not just overcoming external forces, but also rectifying Rufus's mishaps.  Deponia is a comedy. And it plays that part pretty well. As a puzzler, it does okay. Many of the puzzles are quite mathematical and would therefore force the player to seek brute force solutions. Other puzzles require the player to formulate outlandishly complicated solutions to simple problems. Hints are sparse and unhelpful.There is a lot of love that went into this game. The artwork, music, voice acting and scripting are very well done. And for an adventure game, there is a lot of material. The game should last about 10 hours on average.

Posted: September 29, 2014
												This series.What can I say.This ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ series. Has. EVERYTHING that makes a point-and-click adventure game work. Fantastic puzzles, insane and colorful characters, a story that simulateously makes you laugh and cry with Rufus at the same time.Speaking of our egotistical main character, never before have I wanted to give a fictional game character a slap and a hug at the same time. The dude is unbelieveably self-centered, but at the same time he tried his best to keep his shenanigans from harming people. He wants to leave Deponia, but he can't just let people call Deponians trash. The planet? Yeah it's trash, but the people mean well and are just trying to get by, and are in no way trash. This character. This world.THIS SERIES. IS. AMAZING.10/10 GET ALL THREE GAMES IT'S AMAZING.

Posted: September 26, 2014
												Deponia is a comedic point & click adventure game very similar to the Lucas Arts classics Monkey Island and Day of the Tentacle.I'm assuming that you are already familiar with the genre, so I'll keep this short and sweet.Pros:  Fluid animation, high resolution graphics, good soundtrack, interesting plot, funny dialog.Cons:  Puzzles are thrown in with arbitrary handicaps and do not contribute to the plot or integrate well.  The writers got lazy a few times and used the item descriptions from looking at an object as the narration when using the item as well.  It gets annoying hearing the same line multiple times when exploring or experimenting.Recommendation: If you like this sort of game, get it.  You can always look up a walkthrough to deal with the puzzles.  Warning: This comedy in a later episode gets quite dark.  If you cannot stomach Southpark type humor, then you're better off skipping this trilogy.

												It's alright. Deponia is a point-and-click adventure with at least some of the obtuse and convoluted puzzle solving that genre entails. I liked the story as it was certainly interesting, but the character you control is entirely without depth or real personality. Technically speaking, it's an unoptomized mess that runs very poorly and is riddled with bugs.Thankfully, the game allows skipping puzzles because there exists a bug that not only makes one of the puzzles incoherent and unsolvable through normal means, but, even given a working solution, it will not allow progress beyond the puzzle.It's short, but fun. Get it when it's cheap.

Posted: May 31, 2013
												"It's kind of pathetic: you get all erratic, about dirty dishes congesting the sink.I'm tired of your bothers; remember our fathers, who dwelled in a world filled with rubbish and stink..."And so the story begins. Deponia is the tale of Rufus, the son of the man who founded Rufus's hometown of Kuvaq and subsequently disappeared, and his attempts to escape the junk-strewn planet of Deponia. During one of his infamous "perfect" plans, he runs into a girl from the romanticized, junk-free world of Elysium, nearby.The two become wrapped in each other's quests, for better or for worse. Rufus is stuck with Goal, because she's his only ticket out of this dump, and Goal is stuck with Rufus because, well, she's unconscious, and she doesn't really have any say in the matter. Plus he's the person with the closest thing to her best interests at heart, between the town of Kuvaq, who wish to keep her as a trophy resident, and the Organon who seemingly have their own agenda.Rufus is not the most selfless hero. In fact, he's rather vain and self-centered. He manages to pull it off and remain endearing, however - at least to the audience. His neighbors in Kuvaq are painfully tired of his absent-minded and often quite dangerous (to Rufus, and everyone else in a several mile radius) plans and experiments. In a way, maybe I find Rufus endearing because he reminds me so much of, well, me. He's lazy, but dreams big, and feels he deserves to be the one to make it simply because he wants it more.Deponia's a silly game, the kind where great bodily harm is often cartoonishly shrugged off when it's not important to the plot. It made me laugh quite a few times, and most of the characters are well-written and well-voiced. The Organon bug me, with their loud, crackly, sort-of-digitized voices, but most of the others sound alright to downright enjoyable. The music is a perfect fit, evoking the rattling and banging of garbage, while still remaining pleasant to listen to. I'm quite fond of the bar theme in particular, to the point where I would sometimes stop in at the place even after I had no business left there, simply to listen for awhile. The world is beautifully drawn, and most importantly, interesting. There are surprises everywhere, and the world itself is rather unusual, and nicely characterized as you go about your journey.The puzzles are challenging, without ever seeming unfair. You do have kind of an unusual amount of "gather cleaning supplies and clean this thing off" puzzles, but then this IS a planet covered in discarded scrap and refuse, so it's at least justified. On the whole, Deponia's puzzles and style feel to me like a proper evolution of the classic Lucasarts SCUMM adventures. The sense of humor, however, is unique, and I love it. It really feels like Daedalic had fun writing and designing this game, and I'm glad, because I had fun playing it.It's not the longest adventure game, but it's long enough (I clocked about 11 hours of quality adventuring on my playthrough), and I absolutely cannot wait to play the next installment in the Deponia trilogy.And that folk-singer narrator guy ruled!"HUZZAH, HE'S OFF NOW, GOODBYE!"

												To be fair, I started this game because it had a great art style and was a point-and-click adventure (a genre I never really got into). The story ended up being more expansive than I expected at the start, and the quirky character Rufus was really relatable as I helped him towards the goal of Elysium.This game can get really frustrating, because after you figure out most puzzles it doesn't end well for Rufus. After I'd made Rufus' rocket and hit the ship from Elysium, I had to watch him simply fall back to Deponia and continue droning on about escaping with Goal (enough to nearly make me quit the game).Overall, Rufus is a good character with a bunch of puns and a snappy attitude. He doesn't appreciate his friends as much as he should, so most of what happens really seems to be up to his karma. I love the art style and puzzles (although they can be terribly hard), and the music is impossible to get out of your head.

I think it goes without saying that the sequels will be equally unredeemable, so just don't even bother with the series. There are way better point and click adventure games out there that you're actually likely to enjoy.

Posted: May 9, 2014
												This won't be a glowing review. I'll recommend it, but with reservations. If it's on sale for $3.50 or less and you want an interesting, fairly unique story, along with some good adventure game puzzles, then it's a good buy. For any more than that, don't waste your time.So, I'm not an adventure game kinda guy. I didn't like Myst at all, and never got around to many other point-and-click's. A lot felt like pixel hunting and didn't have very logical puzzle solutions. There's very few of those moments in Deponia. Holding the spacebar will reveal all the available hotspots, and many of the solutions make sense. Naturally some seem a little over-complicated, but given the items you're allowed to use they make more sense.The story is interesting, and I found it quite unique. It doesn't give you any agency to change outcomes, but the dialogue driving it is, for the most part, witty and funny.The music is awesome and indeed, the chorus guys rule.Now the bad.This game is horribly, horribly unoptimized. I understand that a few players haven't had any issues, but I spent a lot of time reading the forums and I'm certain that I had every issue mentioned by anyone, and at least one that I didn't see mentioned.The game chugs. I'm not certain why it drops performance so bad, but it does. At first, I thought the animations just had low framerates (The walking animations are fine, as well as the movies by the way. I'm talking about the mouse cursor and inventory screen animations), but at one point there was a sound effect happening in the background at a regular interval. When I pulled up my inventory, or when I pressed spacebar to reveal the hot-spots, the sound effect slowed down by at least half. The game seems to run at around 30fps normally, but was dropping to as low as 5fps during these particular times. I really don't know why a point-and-click should be so resource intensive on a machine that can comfortably run AAA games at high settings.Also, there are a few bugs with not being able to hit certain hotspots at certain times. Trying to exit the listening post is an example. There are workarounds such as talking to the guy who's up there first, but pressing spacebar reveals the exit arrow as an option, so I see no reason it shouldn't be one immediately.The minecart minigame with the correct solution would not allow me to progress. Thankfully they allow you to skip it. Still, that seems like an awful cop-out.One more, that I didn't see anyone ask about, is that the dialogue options would occasionally appear partially above the frame they're enclosed in, thereby obscuring some of the options. Or the options would appear partially below the frame, and therefore partially off-screen thereby rendering some options un-clickable. Cycling through the dialogue options usually fixed the problem. Again, the problem should not exist in the first place.Don't be fooled by the settings, changing them changed nothing about how the game reacted on my machine. Texture compression, weather effects, anything, they all ran exactly the same.Don't be fooled by the demo. The demo ran fine on my machine, full framerates and no dialogue, hotspot, or puzzle issues at all. These were definitely not indicative of the state of the full game.To wrap things up, the game has an interesting story, I like the art style, and it's mostly funny. But, those developers did a terrible job with their QA. Don't buy the game if it's not on sale.

												Deponia is a comedic point & click adventure game very similar to the Lucas Arts classics Monkey Island and Day of the Tentacle.I'm assuming that you are already familiar with the genre, so I'll keep this short and sweet.Pros:  Fluid animation, high resolution graphics, good soundtrack, interesting plot, funny dialog.Cons:  Puzzles are thrown in with arbitrary handicaps and do not contribute to the plot or integrate well. Posted: October 26, 2014
												[Edit: The standalone game has now been patched as well. This means I can recommend the game, with the caveat of checking current special offers (vs The Complete Journey). Leaving the original review below since the bait-and-switch still DID occur.]Good game BUT a word of warning:Deponia and it's sequels are since september 2014 presumably abandonware. Instead of patching the remaining bugs of the separate games the developer/publisher Daedalic decided to release an all-in-one title called Deponia: The Complete Journey. It's a completely new separate title, not a 'pack' containing the previous games, so there is no way to upgrade from the standalone titles. It also does not create giftable versions of the titles you already own.If you are new to the game and want to buy and play Deponia (which is a terrific and fun Point-and-Click) get The Complete Journey.Personally I think this move is blatantly unfriendly to early adopters and existing customers and would probably not buy anything from Daedalic again, let alone this new all-in-one version.

Posted: January 25, 2015
												This is a hard game to review.   It's a game with a strong storyline and some genuinely funny dialogue.  The puzzles occasionally lack much logic and can sometimes only be solved through guesswork (or by referring to a walkthrough) but this is a common problem with point-and-click adventure games and I would say that it's no worse than its peers in that regard.However, it's not a game that everyone will enjoy.    Whereas other adventure game characters like Guybrush Threepwood are hapless and inept, the protagonist of this game, Rufus, is rude, selfish, callous, sexist and egocentric.   This is a protagonist who you should probably not identify with or even sympathise with (although you probably will as you get drawn into the narrative)The humour is mostly derived from Rufus creating plans that go wrong and behaving in such a way as to cause misery and misfortune to those around them.   This is of course a well-established form of black comedy and I think that most people will be able to take it as it was intended.However, there are a number of jokes that contain elements that are as likely to cause offence and upset rather than amusement.   There are three main instances of this (from the entire trilogy):- One character is depicted in a very transphobic light- One character suffers through a racially demeaning situation (due to the protagonist)- One character is a paedophileThese are all intended as jokes and the author of the game has clarified that racially charged scene was not meant to convey a positive message about racism (the humour is derived from how awful the situation is) but it may still limit the ability of some people to enjoy the game.If you particularly enjoy point-and-click games and can tolerate the occasionally moment of humour in bad taste then you will enjoy this game.   If you are sensitive about racism, transphobia or sex crime then you may find that some jokes spoil your ability to enjoy the rest of the game.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												Deponia was something I picked up on a whim during the Steam flash sale, I've been a fan of point & clicks in the past (such as Monkey Island games) and had seen mixed reviews about Deponia; but thought at that price it was worth the risk.I suspect Deponia is one of those games that you'll either love or absolutely hate - many reviews I saw complained about the "annoying main character", personally, I actually quite liked him and thought the dialogue was very fitting for the game.I am extremely glad that I picked this up, the game was fun, interesting and I even liked the art style.Deponia has manageable achievements - it's the first Steam game I've actually gotten round to getting all the achievements for. The vast majority of them you will pick up from just playing the game (provided you don't skip the puzzles) though some you may end up missing if you don't explore every possibility.The one disappointment was that I did experience two bugs where I was unable to proceed and had to go back to earlier saves (thankfully I saved plenty of times so only had to replay 15 minutes or so of the game) and for that I am gong to take a couple of points off my final score.Overall, Deponia provided everything I wanted from a point & click, it has a decent story and kept my attention throughout the game.My rating: 8/10 - A good fun way to spend a few hours, in an interesting world with a lovely art style.The game's bugs were a minor annoyance, but I found solutions to both with a quick Google.Looking for an interesting point & click to spend a few hours on? Deponia's your game. Recommended - I'll be playing the next one very soon!

Posted: October 26, 2014
												[Edit: The standalone game has now been patched as well. This means I can recommend the game, with the caveat of checking current special offers (vs The Complete Journey). Leaving the original review below since the bait-and-switch still DID occur.]Good game BUT a word of warning:Deponia and it's sequels are since september 2014 presumably abandonware. Instead of patching the remaining bugs of the separate games the developer/publisher Daedalic decided to release an all-in-one title called Deponia: The Complete Journey. It's a completely new separate title, not a 'pack' containing the previous games, so there is no way to upgrade from the standalone titles. It also does not create giftable versions of the titles you already own.If you are new to the game and want to buy and play Deponia (which is a terrific and fun Point-and-Click) get The Complete Journey.Personally I think this move is blatantly unfriendly to early adopters and existing customers and would probably not buy anything from Daedalic again, let alone this new all-in-one version.

												Just finished part 3 of this trilogy (Deponia, Chaos on Deponia and Goodbye Deponia) and decided to write a review for the whole series. Of course it's only right to place it here, where the story starts.At heart this is a classic point and click adventure. A genre claimed to be dead, but getting "ressurected" from now and then by talanted indi-storytellers. This time it's Daedalic, a company of which I've never heard before (though they do seem to have several pretty critically acclaimed games out at this point, so it might be just my ignorance) with their take on humour, creativity and random fun. =)This game reminds me of the Runaway series, witty and charming main protagonist goes through unlikely events during a trilogy growing up and becoming a bit better.Actually, just play this game if you miss the point&click fun, you won't regret.PS. The ending somewhat... left me hanging. >_<

Posted: January 21, 2014
												If you like point and click adventure gameplay, then you will probably like this game. There really aren't any new mechanics. The player can double click on any transition point leading to another area in order to quick travel to that area, and the play can also middle click to show points of interest in the current area. These are very nice convenience features which help to stave off frustration.If you play games for storytelling, then you might like this game. The voice acting is pretty good in my opinion. I thought that the dialog was witty for the most part, but the main character is a self-centered jerk. I'm hoping that he becomes more selfless in the second and third Deponia games. The heroine is likable.The art style is very good in my opinion. It vaguely reminds me of the aesthetic of World of Goo.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												Deponia is a adventure game of the type I like the most. Challenging puzzles, cartoony 2D-graphics, no action elemements and a good humorous story.The best aspect of the game is probably the creative andsometimes quite challenging puzzles. In some adventure games the solution to a puzzle is almost immediately obvious because there are so few possible things to try. In Deponia trial and error is not a quick and easy approach, since there are many objects and lots of things to interact with. In particular in the first part of the game the puzzles require a bit of out of the box thinking without being unfair. Puzzles are also fairly varied and always feel like a natural part of the game rather than tacked on. My only complaint in this department is that the very end of the game is a bit anticlimactic in terms of puzzle difficulty.The story is humorous and entertaining with unique character. The humour doesn't always work, but there are moments of brilliance, and it worked often enough to keep me entertained throughout. The ending is a bit disappointing but it does leave things at an appropriate starting point for the sequel.The cartoony graphics are entirely appropriate given the general tone of the game and are high quality and quite distinctive. Characters each have their own unique appearance and do not look generic at all like they do in too many games.Voice acting is above average but not exceeptional. The music has a unique style that is very appropriate given the particular setting and is quite appealing too.All in all this is a highly recommended adventure game if you like pure point and click adventures with challenging puzzles and a healthy dose of humour.

The rest can continue to read - Rather interesting story, which is the mayor goal for adventure games like these. A strong character as well. As I read other reviews, many people disliked Rufus for being arrogant and an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Well, that's how the creators wanted him to be. Not all games are made how you want them to be. Especially in adventure games, you are playing the story, that creators want to tell you, and I respect that. Visual effects could be better, but they are no reason to not enjoy this game. Posted: January 6, 2014
												The puzzles are challenging, forcing you to adopt a non-traditional form of logic to solve them. The main character is so self-centered, he's delusional. Most importantly, the story is quite amusing and well written. The jokes range from cartoon slapstick to innuendo to bizzarre WTF situations. But the story, despite the juvenile humour, creates a full character arc. If you decide to play all the way to "Goodbye Deponia" you will be surprised by a beautiful and touching ending. I highly recommend this game if you want something that makes you think and experiment or a fun interactive story.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												I have very mixed feelings about this game. There were some parts of the game that were genuinely funny, which was the goal of the developer of this comedy-based adventure game. There were some puzzles that were really fun and challenging. Unfortunately, there are some major problems in this game that made me consider abandoning it at several points. Some of the puzzles try to be cute and absurd rather than logical, which make them hard to solve other than trial and error. There are some puzzles where the cue to the player is not obvious enough. There are also parts of the game where it is not clear what you are supposed to do next. For example, in many adventure games if you talk to characters in the game, they will tend to point you toward your next task. The characters in Deponia will tell you tons of jokes and wierd stories (I clicked through a lot of it), but 90% of the dialog has nothing to do with helping you finish the game. There are some out-and-out bugs, including a minigame that was flat broken. I used a walk-through more for this game than any other I have ever played (that includes Myst, Riven, Siberia I/II, Machinarium, The Longest Journey, etc). The hero of the story was a little too detestable to be funny. The artwork, style, and creativity were all there for this to be an excellent game, but somehow the developers did not learn from other great games of this genre. The result is a disappointment.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												As a big fan of adventure point-and-click games, I jumped on this one as soon as I saw it. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to all the fans of games like this.The story isn't very exciting, but it is interesting. From time to time you will be frustrated because the things didn't go as planned even though you tried so hard with a puzzle or an annoying conversation. The main character, Rufus, will annoy you to no end with his ego tripping and, well, stupidity. You will find yourself yelling at him or mentally high-fiving him. Other characters are interesting and have stories to tell you and are very helpful. And of course, there's a love interest. The puzzles are mostly fun, although some of them you will gladly skip, which you can. If you are like me and don't have internet access often, you will be glad to know that your achievements will still be saved. Graphically-wise, the game is gorgeous, the comicbook-y style goes well with the humour-filled conversation. Voice acting is also very good. All in all, a very good point-and-click adventure that will make you happy and angry at the same time.

												What can I say? My first adventure game I completed was Leisure Suit Larry in the Land of Lounge Lizards in late 80's, and I have been fan of adventure game genre ever since. Posted: October 9, 2014
												Deponia is an excellent adventure game that exudes charm and polish, even if that polish is spotty at times. I'd say this is a very approachable game that anyone can play and enjoy. The puzzles are tricky but fair, and require a lot of thinking outside the box, which is exactly what they should. I especially love how the dialogue gives hints towards what you need to do with a particular puzzle. Deponia is quirky and funny, and if you love Monkey Island you'll love this. The language is stronger than in LucasArts' adventure games, but infrequent and still on the mild side.A few bits where Deponia could use improvement: the subtitles are occasionally mispelled, the voice acting sounds forced or awkward occasionally, and I've run into a few glitches, although nothing game-breaking. 9/10, highly recommended.

Posted: September 15, 2016
												Deponia brings the classic point and click animated adventure games to a new level of quality. A modern series of games with a system and artwork that might bring Leisure Suit Larry to mind, packed with a lot of humor and abstract situations. There's a plethora of characters with their unique personalities and tons of interesting stuff happening in the plot.It certainly is one of the best games in the point and click genre, yet it's not flawless. One of the flaws is that there are moments where you're clueless as of what you're supposed to do. You're stuck, trying to figure out what to do/where to use an object. After consulting with a solution, it turns out that the thing you didn't know was so ridiculous that you'd probably spend hours on trying to figure it out, and still not get it. + amazing humor+ very long+ original story+ interesting characters- many spots that are easy to get stuck at

												A fun, short indie point and click adventure game. Posted: October 22, 2016
												This was a fun point-and-click with enough challenging puzzles to keep me interested, but a bit lacklustre in other areas. I liked the premise - a world built on a junk yard - and I likedthat many of the puzzles required you to get creative and build things out of unconventional materials. I did get stuck a few times and had to look up prompts, which I hate doing, but it helped me think about future puzzles differently so I didn't need help towards the end. While the voice acting was decent enough, I found the characters to be quite generic, and I did not care for Rufus's weird creepy possessiveness of Goal as some kind of prize (even her name alludes to this). My main annoyance was that this game has way too much unnecessary dialogue; I put the subtitles on so I could quickly skip through the lines unless they had some useful information. The dialogue was often trying to be funny but much of it was fluff. I like this kind of Monkey Island style game with quirky humour, and there was some of that, but a lot of it could have been cut. The ending was a bit abrupt. I didn't really care for the storyline towards the end; it felt rushed and the puzzles became fewer and further between to make way for overindulgent cut scenes. Overall I enjoyed it, but I'm glad I got it at the sale price.

Posted: October 9, 2014
												Deponia is an excellent adventure game that exudes charm and polish, even if that polish is spotty at times. I'd say this is a very approachable game that anyone can play and enjoy. The puzzles are tricky but fair, and require a lot of thinking outside the box, which is exactly what they should. I especially love how the dialogue gives hints towards what you need to do with a particular puzzle. Deponia is quirky and funny, and if you love Monkey Island you'll love this. The language is stronger than in LucasArts' adventure games, but infrequent and still on the mild side.A few bits where Deponia could use improvement: the subtitles are occasionally mispelled, the voice acting sounds forced or awkward occasionally, and I've run into a few glitches, although nothing game-breaking. 9/10, highly recommended.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												Whimsical point and click adventure. It's a colorful little world and a nice addition to a faded genre, but it displays some telltale signs of why the genre has faded. You'll hit at least a handful of moments where the game becomes less about figuring out clever little puzzles and more about trying every different thing on every other thing until something works. Also, the voice acting is unfortunately pretty terrible. so much so, that you might even consider muting it so you don't have to hear the same lines repeated over and over again as you progress through dialogue trees. The game took me about 10 hours to complete, but I was ready for it to be over after about 6.This is first in a trilogy. If you like point-and-click, it will entertain. But I'd recommend trying this one out before pulling the trigger on the complete Deponia series.

Posted: October 27, 2016
												I'd recommend it on a sale anyday.For the full price however, no.It's good, not perfect. The humor is cringeworthy at times, which I won't hold against them, since it's hard to make good humor at times. It does however have that "Saturday-morning cartoon" wich I like. It doesn't work in all games, but Deponia managed to pull it off more or less. I really like the visuals, makes me think of "The inner world", which also delivers the sam feeling. However, that games has a very uniqe and intresting setting, which this game fell short with sometimes. The story was something that took time before it got interesting, but in the end I was satified. Up until the ending however it felt like I was taking baby steps, and that I was making slow progress all the time. This could also have had to do with the fact that your goal was always the same.  What I have specifically in mind was the fact that you always have oyur focus on waking up Goal, fixing her brain implant and what not. It felt att times that she was not a character, but an object that I had to fix. Not until the end did this change, when she revealed her persenality and emotions towards your actions (like wanting to get to Elyssium). From what I've seen from the later games, thsi should change and she will have a bigger impact on the story.  The puzzels were alright, not to farfetched, which might happen to games that involves puzzels and humor.In conclusion, if you have some time over (I was between assignments at uni) and if you find it on sale, then give it a go.

The balance in this game is perfection, humour, style, depth of character, engaging story, challenging puzzles, it has it all and it's one game I could never tire of.You play as Rufus, the unfortunate dweller of the Deponia junk piles, who wants to make his life better by going to Elysium in the sky, the problem? Posted: November 5, 2016
												Beautifully drawn, funny, with actually pretty good story (and world setting) masked by simple personal quest of an egocentric protagonist. But also Deponia is a time machine with a dial set to 90's which had twofold effect on me:First I remembered playing good old P&C adventures, warm and cosy feeling with occasional chuckle, and of course accompanied with frustrations because of illogical solutions and pixel hunting. But during those days we didn't have internet so you would be stuck on a certain puzzle for hours/days, repeating your steps making sure you didn't miss anything vital (did I mention illogical?) figuring out that you are dumb after all... Ahh *wipes the tear of reminiscence*Second thing is that I realized why this genre has died out. I can't imagine someone who grew up with today's games enjoying this kind of experience. Nothing here is on platter, you have to figure out on your own how to solve it. Or of course go and find a walk-through online, but they you would ask yourself are you enjoying this or even if is this is for you. So you would drop it and go play something in 3D with jumping and shooting with immediate satisfaction.If this came out in previous century it would be masterpiece worth remembering.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												I wasn't a huge fan of Point and Click games, until this came out.Deponia has good gameplay mechanics, which only take a minute to learn. The way you solve puzzle in this game, and progress the story is by actually using your brain, instead of mashing buttons. I'm not saying you need an above average intelligence to complete it; but it will sometimes make you think.Now, with the gameplay mechanic out of the way - let's talk about the story. This has got to be one of the most fun stories out there for games, or at-least - the point and click genre. It has been a pretty solid base story, with some nice humour thrown in too. Although the humour could be seen as a bit low brow - but it goes well with the base story and the "Hero".If you like point and click games, I'm going to assume you have already bought this game within seconds of watching the intro. If you aren't a point and click fan - much like myself before this series - then there is always a first game to get you rolling, and this is it. I now love all of Daederic Entertainment' games. Thank you for porting Edna to IOS. please consider this in the future too.Thank you so much for such a great game.

Posted: March 31, 2016
												$20 for this ?  Fortunately I got the game for only $2 on sale, but I can't help imagining how disappointed I would have been if I had paid full price for it.  10 hours is no small amount of game time but the plot barely advances at all over the course of the game.  Half of my time playing was spent making a cup of espresso, and the rest of the game just rushes by without anything actually happening.  The game ended right when I thought it was getting started.  None of the questions that were introduced in the exposition of the game were resolved at the end, and instead it only made the story even more ambiguous without any closure.  This game is completely useless without owning the sequels, which only seems like a way of cheaply breaking up the story for more money, when this one is being sold at twice the price that it should be.This game showed a lot of promise at the start.  It's set in a unique and interesting world that I had no problem getting into (in no small part due to the phenomenal art direction), the protagonist is a relatably uncharismatic outcast who became increasingly likable as his surroundings (namely his disdainful and unsympathetic neighbors) became more developed, the hero's actions and motives are clear and understandable despite his overt rudeness and dim-witted sense of grandiosity, it has an engaging sense of humor, and the good soundtrack and voice acting only added to the charm of the game.  With so much done right, it's incredible that anything could go wrong.Unfortunately the plot just becomes a mess once the final area is reached and the last chunk of story is delivered all at once just before it's abruptly ended.  The last area consists of a frustrating back and forth that ultimately brings the protagonist right back to the start just when it felt like the game was finally getting somewhere, that is Elysium, the place that the player and the character have both been trying to reach the whole time.  It gets so close to reaching this goal that it felt like the real plot was artificially snatched away at the last second simply so that a sequel could be made.My suggestion is that you should play this game if it looks appealing, but be prepared to get forced into a whole series and definitely do not buy it at full price.  I personally enjoyed Deponia and will probably be buying the game's sequels myself if they go on sale sometime, but I can't recommend playing it at the current price of $20.

												Excellent adventure game -- a lot of humor.One interesting aspect of Deponia: You play Rufus, a protagonist whose character answers the question "How would a real-life person who grabs everything that is not nailed down behave?" You know the type [non-spoiler examples by the way]-- the one who insists that there is a perfectly viable reason to for example break into a museum at night to break a priceless ming vase because there might be something inside, and is sincerely apologetic he needed an amputee's prosthetic leg to knock a kite out of a tree instead of buying one from the store. One aspect: This is a game whose absurdity occasionally extends to puzzle design. So you will probably need either a walk-through or a large dose of experimentation to solve everything. Just don't click on the commentary boxes until your second play-through.

Posted: March 29, 2015
												Daedalic's Deponia is easily recommended even though it has a few flaws and, for me, a challenging design decision, i.e. the b-a-stard main character. It is well crafted, so main aspects like story, style, user interface and voice acting are almost all of the time great - in that way where you don't have to think about them since you hardly stumble over anything to be irritated much less annoyed by.+ Beautiful comic style graphics+ Awesome intermission songs+ Very good voice acting - believable characters+ Good story+ Mostly very good game/puzzle logic, + Shortcuts to menus, quick-save and quick-load, fast access via inventory+ Drogglejug- Multi-minute bl(a/o)ckscreen when starting and quitting the game- Dislikeable main character that I want to slap in the face from time to time- Some graphical glitches- Some subtitle glitches- Sometimes unnecessarily loud sound pieces- Unnerving background music (at the start, see below)Hints:* F5: Save/load menu* F9 + F10: quick-save + quick-load* If your game starts with an inescapable black screen give it time, maybe 5 minutes. It resolved after 3-4 minutes by itself on my machine.Backgrounds, characters and items are with two exceptions beautiful and interesting and are probably what brought you to the store page. The two exceptions were the two states of a mousetrap in the inventory. By the looks of it the image was read out wrong and thus skewed. In some cases the background panel for dialogue choices was missing.The voice acting is superb and characters are portrayed with consistency thus contributing to mysterious, outlandish (in a good way) story.I do despise the main character and the way you have to go along with his egotistical and destructive reflections, disregard and actions - there is one decision forced on the player much alike "Why use the door handle when you can break down the door?" However, that character is also consistent and driving the story. Also, he makes practically every other character pretty likeable - his ex even before she enters the screen. I do hope the final scenes are supposed to indicate a change of character, i.e. a future moderation and an emergence of care for othersI can't say much about the background music of the game since it quickly became unnerving enough for me to mute it and so I don't know whether it improved later on. However, the intermission songs are despite there shortness awesome - think Bard's Tale songs. And they really cracked me up in Drogglejug mode.A few times some very loud sound pieces or music were played, e.g. when making "the discovery" coming back to the candy store. Also, Argus is too loud. I would have wished for those to be tuned down with the other volume settings.I really liked the interface, e.g. how the mousewheel seamlessly brings in and out the inventory. I think it an ingenious idea to have a shortcut to the save/load menu from the inventory and I applaud the employment of F-keys.The game logic is sound and puzzle threads are well graspable so that the player can follow the story without much stumbling.I really liked Drogglejug mode. It took me forever to get the reference even though multiple related hints appear throughout the game, e.g. the globe.Two more flaws:1. Sometimes the subtitles glitched from English to German.2. A major, almost off-putting, problem are the blocking black screens that happen when starting or quitting the game. With their three to five minute resolution time - all while catching any keyboard event, e.g. Alt+Tab, Ctrl+Alt+Del, Ctrl+Shift+Esc - I think a lot of people may have hard-reset their machines before realising the problem would resolve itself with time.I had the luxury of having another machine on my desk that I could use to search for the problem thus not experiencing the minutes as pure waiting time, otherwise I would have restarted machine 1 after less than 2 minutes. And I refrained from quitting the game in order to write this review without delay. So it's waiting time for me next.In case I didn't make it clear so far, I enjoyed Deponia :)I was looking forward to playing it and wasn't disappointed. And after my 3.5 play-throughs I'm looking forward to the sequel: Chaos on Deponia.Huzzah Drogglejug!

Posted: September 3, 2016
												I have long since been a fan of adventure games ever since I traipsed around the disc as Rincewind the hopeless wizard and solving the ancient mystery of the Templars in Broken sword, feeling the itch for adventure once more I looked to cure the malady with the first Deponia an adventure game set in a world overflowing with garbage and rust.Amusingly enough I find myself following the antics of a young, optimistic if not misguided and cursed individual called Rufus who can't help but destroy nearly everything he comes into contact with, With my previous experience of the adventure genre it didnt take long to acclimate myself with the user interface and inventory systems even so a newcomer to the genre would find it easy to navigate the vibrant world around them and have help from the game itself with the press of a button.From start to finish I played through colourful environments with a smile on my face as I watched on at Rufus' attempts to converse with wacky characters and overcome the problems he was faced with often with disasterous results but still couldn't stop myself from laughing at his misfortune, the plot though simple was still absorbing enough to keep my interest and managed to throw plenty of curveballs so much so I can't wait to get to continue the advenuture and see what mischief Rufus manages to get himself into.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												The whole Deponia series comprises some of my favourite point-and-click adventure games. They're fun, hilarious, and for the most part the puzzle solutions made sense but were still challenging. The story itself is fantastic, and full of laughs. The gameplay I never found tedious or boring, and there are no tiny hotspots that you just can't quite click that make some other point-and-click games so frustrating. The voice acting, music, and especially the art are all very well done. I highly recommend all the games in this series, but this first is my favourite of the four, and if you're only ever going to play one Daedalic Entertainment game, this should be it!

Posted: April 3, 2016
												I'm a fan of the old point and click games, I grew up with Monkey Island and Grim Fandango. I've yet to find something similar that captures the humour, atmosphere and style of those games. Deponia seemed like a good, recent take on the genre so I thought I'd give it a shot. If you're a fan of point and click adventure games, I would recommend it. Otherwise, I'd say try Monkey Island first (particularly the remastered versions if nostalgia alone isn't enough to see past the older graphics.)Deponia is ok all round, the art style is pretty cool and the environments are well drawn. The dialogue is pretty hit and miss though, and if I'm honest I didn't find it all that funny. One thing that really stood out to me as quite poor was the sound design. Some of the sound effects get really repetitive, to the point of being annoying in some scenes, and the robotic effect on the Organon voices were far too loud and irritating. The music isn't great, although the mechanical sounding elements lend themself well to the locations and world, they just lacked the charm that I've heard in other point & click adventure classics.The characters are ok, a little underdeveloped but the storyline is fairly decent. Doc and Bozo deserved more introduction in my opinion.The puzzles on the most part are logical, with enough hint in the dialogue frome looking at objects to help you along but there are the occasional frustrating puzzles that I admit I couldn't figure out on my own. Overall, it's worth getting this if you're a fan of the point & click genre, but I'd grab it while it's on sale.

												This was my second attempt to make it threw this game. I finally completed it and I enjoyed it. The main character Rufus doesn't really grow to much, you don't really make any connection with him because he repeatedly goes against his morals and you want the main character to be the one that defies all of the odds to stick to his guns. The jokes were good, I found the game quite amusing, it was light hearted and silly and I laughed out loud.The major problem with this game is the puzzle mechanics. The beginning is ok and the end makes sense but the middle part that takes place in the village has a lot of random trying everything in your inventory with everything else. They were grasping at straws and when I read a walkthrough to help me when I got stuck I realized I would NEVER have thought of the solution. I have played many adventure games but this one just got frustrating. I would still recommend it, I thought the artwork was great and the jokes were as well. Posted: August 11, 2015
												May I present: Rufus. Our protagonist (technically true) and hero (not true even after three servings of cactus juice).He lives in Deponia. He hates Deponia. Deponia hates him.Now that you know the inter-relational dynamics of the situation, let me tell you something more about Rufus.He has flaws. And by that I mean he is a glib-tongued, self-absorbed, egotistical megalomaniac with inclinations for projects from the 'mad scientist' category. He might also be an arsonist. And he steals. Like, a lot. For example, if you have a firefly-powered miner's hat on you and Rufus is in the vicinity, chances are you don't really have it. Maybe you never even had it to start with? You just thought you had it? See...?Normally I try my best to avoid surrounding myself or even being associated with those kinds of people. But there's just something in him, you know? Not his brains, he has proven more than once that he is a little slow on the uptake, if you catch my drift. I have no idea how he does it but he makes me a worse person with each and every meeting we have. I admit, he got me so hooked that I took the bait (*hint*hint*), line and sinker and started playing Chaos on Deponia immediately after finishing this one.Rufus! Oh, the fun we've had! The only downside to it all is that I am afraid my moral compass isn't pointing north as much as it used to.

Posted: November 5, 2016
												Beautifully drawn, funny, with actually pretty good story (and world setting) masked by simple personal quest of an egocentric protagonist. But also Deponia is a time machine with a dial set to 90's which had twofold effect on me:First I remembered playing good old P&C adventures, warm and cosy feeling with occasional chuckle, and of course accompanied with frustrations because of illogical solutions and pixel hunting. But during those days we didn't have internet so you would be stuck on a certain puzzle for hours/days, repeating your steps making sure you didn't miss anything vital (did I mention illogical?) figuring out that you are dumb after all... Ahh *wipes the tear of reminiscence*Second thing is that I realized why this genre has died out. I can't imagine someone who grew up with today's games enjoying this kind of experience. Nothing here is on platter, you have to figure out on your own how to solve it. Or of course go and find a walk-through online, but they you would ask yourself are you enjoying this or even if is this is for you. So you would drop it and go play something in 3D with jumping and shooting with immediate satisfaction.If this came out in previous century it would be masterpiece worth remembering.

Posted: September 15, 2016
												Deponia brings the classic point and click animated adventure games to a new level of quality. A modern series of games with a system and artwork that might bring Leisure Suit Larry to mind, packed with a lot of humor and abstract situations. There's a plethora of characters with their unique personalities and tons of interesting stuff happening in the plot.It certainly is one of the best games in the point and click genre, yet it's not flawless. One of the flaws is that there are moments where you're clueless as of what you're supposed to do. You're stuck, trying to figure out what to do/where to use an object. After consulting with a solution, it turns out that the thing you didn't know was so ridiculous that you'd probably spend hours on trying to figure it out, and still not get it. + amazing humor+ very long+ original story+ interesting characters- many spots that are easy to get stuck at

Posted: August 6, 2016
												Do I really need to write a review for this game? Probably not. But I enjoyed this and the following games in the series so much, I just feel I have to add my voice to all the other voices of praise for Deponia. This game really sparked my excitement for gaming again. I don't know how to write an organized review, so I'll just ramble off some points. :) The thing that makes this game gold is the writing. All of the characters are well developed and charming.  Even the hilariously self-absorbed Rufus. I feel like this is one of the more unique games I have played. If you want to figure out all of the puzzles on your own without a guide, you will spend hours at some points, wracking your brain, thinking creatively... The solutions you (Rufus) come up with to advance are not immediately obvious and are very clever. It can get frustrating, but it is very rewarding when you put things together. Such a smart and comedic game. The atmosphere is so unique and the artwork is fantastic. The experience only gets better in the next games as the story developes, so be prepared to spend some time in this universe. I'm so glad I did!

I really enjoyed this part, is the more mature of the trilogy, while the second and third have somehow more childish quests. Great game!

Posted: January 29, 2016
												I wanted to like this game. I really did. TL; DR If you like mindles click spam puzzle games that require zero logic, then I guess you should get it.The story is not too bad and the graphics are really nice.  .......but.What made me give a negative review is the puzzle solving mechanism which is just..horrible. 95% of the time there are absolutely no hints or clues about what you have to do next. You picked up some items because you cliked on everything that was clickable; tho using this items requires multiple spamming, usually just trying to use every item from your inventory on an object (only to find out neither of those are meant to be used and then doing the same on next object, etc.), or trying to connect all the items in your inventory together in hope you're going to craft something useful. And sometimes these crafted objects made absolutely zero sense.The walking and overall moving was very badly done and often very very annoying, and the jokes are just.. Not funny. I can see it tries hard to be funny but it's just not. Also the characters are one of the most annoying I have ever met in the game.I finished the game, but I had to keep the walktrough opened at all times because at most times I had zero idea about what to do next since there is absolutely no hints.I hope the other sequels are done better on this point.

Posted: January 21, 2016
												A fantastic adventure game, featuring some extremely intelligent riddles that require deep thinking. At the same time, it narrates a beautiful story, one that takes place in a setting very different than those of most adventure games. Recommended for everyone interested in the genre, It offers a classic, challenging gameplay, which should be enough to keep fans of the adventures games playing till they finish it. The controls and voice acting is top notch. The storyline is humerous and fun. However, the ending was a total buildup for the second installment. A tad dissapointing. There is about 8 - 15 hours of gameplay, depending how long it takes you to do the puzzles. At best the game is worth only $15. Seeing how you will most likely need all three installments for some closer, the total package could be worth $30 if you get about 10 hours of gameplay out of each installment. I will get the other installments when they go on sale.

Posted: March 3, 2016
												Deponia is a point-and-click adventure game reminiscent of the Lucasarts classics. It tells the story of eternal screwup and egomaniac Rufus and his efforts to escape the garbage-filled planet he lives on to reach a floating city, Elysium.All in all, the game is well paced, funny, and the right mix of challenging and logical. There was no singular moment where I was just baffled over an answer, though the game does offer large enviroments that can sometimes be overwhelming.If you are a fan of the genre, this game (and it's sequels) should definitely be in your collection, but it certainly won't be worth it to those who are not.

												Easily my favourite point and click adventure game, and when I say 'adventure' I mean it, I have become so enthralled in the story and progression that I played it into the small hours of the morning without realising.
