Posted: August 10, 2013
												Feels like a classic 90s LucasArts comedy game. That's both a good and a bad thing, really.The good:- Great art.- Rock solid voice acting.- The puzzles don't quite get as obscure or ridiculous as 90s adventures, which is a good thing since there's nothing like the infamous Monkey Wrench puzzle here.- Some neat innovations in 90s adventure game playability. Clicking the middle mouse button highlights objects you can interact with, whilst scrolling it brings down your inventory. Feels natural.- Characters are mostly good. I feel Rufus has a good progression from self-centered idiot to someone who actually wants to do good by the end, and that's a nice progression. Other characters serve the plot well too, except for Goal (see below).- The setting of Deponia feels very alive, like a lived-in place with backstory, and not just a shoestrung setting for some doofus causing havoc.The bleh:- Animation is a mixed bag.- Humour is also mixed. Some jokes are funny, others not so. I think the visual gags work well, whereas the "witty" puns fall flat eight times out of ten. That's what you get when translating German jokes, I guess.- Goal's character. Don't know anything about her, since she's barely awake for most of the game. Can't say she's particularly bad, but I'm unconvinced she's a worthwhile heroine at this point.- The plot is interesting, but largely unremarkable, especially the romance. It's kind of the typical 'save the world and win the girl as a trophy' trope that's all tired out. As far as that goes it's competent, but I'd have liked to have had a better motivator.The bad:- The ending is a total bummer, and you feel like you've accomplished nothing.- Some plot threads I feel should've been addressed in this game, have instead been held off for the sequel.- Some puzzles feel obscure, and only after accidentally solving them do you "get it". I felt I stumbled into as many solutions on Deponia as I had eureka moments, which felt very unsatisfying.All told, I think the good outweighs the bad, and none of the bleh moments particularly spoiled the game. If you like 90s LucasArts comedy games (Monkey Island 1-3, Day of the Tentacle, Sam & Max, and the like) then you will probably get your money's worth out of Deponia, and not feel like you've wasted your time.

Posted: January 8, 2015
												Super funny! I like the main character for being a self-absorbed jerk. It's nice not play a goodie-two-shoes for a change and I love all the sarcasm and hatred he encounters when speaking with others and how he is a derp and is often oblivious to it. I like how even when he does realize it, it doesn't stop/affect him.This may be a spoiler but I have to say that: In the end of the game, I honestly did feel sorry for him. I mean, we don't know why he is exactly the way he is to begin with. His father left him behind, he is probably emotionally scarred. His life on Deponia doesn't work out. He knows (or at least thinks) that his dad made it to Elysium so he wants to go too. It's not like I'd enjoy living on a smelly planet either you know. Probably the fact he thinks he will leave Deponia soon, causes him not to want to put in any effort on his life or bonds on Deponia, and rather put in all his efforts into finally get Elysium. (And perhaps seeing his dad again) although it's said that his dad was apparently selfish too so whatever. I mean I am fine with him being selfish, at least he is up front about it. In the end, every person is selfish or at least at times but they try to hide it. :P Rufus could have played himself off as not selfish and simply wanting to help Goal the entire way, and reached his actual goal in the end, but instead he was up front about his intentions in the end and also came clean which came from the heart. I can appreciate this characer for that simply because even if he may seem a jerk, at least he stays true to himself. There are plenty of people who seem to do something for another but secretly only do it for a selfish motive, no? So if you hate Rufus please go do some self-reflection. LOLAlbeit I felt sorry for Toni for having to deal with him the way he is though, I still think she is rather stupid for continueing to allow Rufus to stay in her home. I mean, does she still love him or something? If someone would live in my house and did that stuff I'd kick them out mercilessly. Didn't really understand the charm of Goal at all, she seemed like some kind of robotic person, reminded me of Chobits (it's an anime) which I guess is nice in a sense but she was most of the time just asleep so we didn't get to know her personality at all unfortunately.The game's puzzles were fun and combining items in your inventory was as well, although I at times couldn't figure out what to do after trying out tons of ways without any result. Thankfully there are walkthroughs on the internet but I really wished that hadn't been necesarry. The puzzles are all logical, yes, but sometimes there just isn't enough hinting towards what you could do or objects that you can use aren't really obvious, I've had several times where I moved my mouse past an item I could have picked up but it did not show it at the time. This still didn't get in the way of me appreciating the comical aspects, settings, and character interactions in this game, so much in fact, that I recommend it to anyone who has a more dark sense of humor and doesn't get offended easily by jokes that revolve around degradation, or a characters whose considered a selfish jerk in general. :P

Posted: March 29, 2015
												Daedalic's Deponia is easily recommended even though it has a few flaws and, for me, a challenging design decision, i.e. the b-a-stard main character. It is well crafted, so main aspects like story, style, user interface and voice acting are almost all of the time great - in that way where you don't have to think about them since you hardly stumble over anything to be irritated much less annoyed by.+ Beautiful comic style graphics+ Awesome intermission songs+ Very good voice acting - believable characters+ Good story+ Mostly very good game/puzzle logic, + Shortcuts to menus, quick-save and quick-load, fast access via inventory+ Drogglejug- Multi-minute bl(a/o)ckscreen when starting and quitting the game- Dislikeable main character that I want to slap in the face from time to time- Some graphical glitches- Some subtitle glitches- Sometimes unnecessarily loud sound pieces- Unnerving background music (at the start, see below)Hints:* F5: Save/load menu* F9 + F10: quick-save + quick-load* If your game starts with an inescapable black screen give it time, maybe 5 minutes. It resolved after 3-4 minutes by itself on my machine.Backgrounds, characters and items are with two exceptions beautiful and interesting and are probably what brought you to the store page. The two exceptions were the two states of a mousetrap in the inventory. By the looks of it the image was read out wrong and thus skewed. In some cases the background panel for dialogue choices was missing.The voice acting is superb and characters are portrayed with consistency thus contributing to mysterious, outlandish (in a good way) story.I do despise the main character and the way you have to go along with his egotistical and destructive reflections, disregard and actions - there is one decision forced on the player much alike "Why use the door handle when you can break down the door?" However, that character is also consistent and driving the story. Also, he makes practically every other character pretty likeable - his ex even before she enters the screen. I do hope the final scenes are supposed to indicate a change of character, i.e. a future moderation and an emergence of care for othersI can't say much about the background music of the game since it quickly became unnerving enough for me to mute it and so I don't know whether it improved later on. However, the intermission songs are despite there shortness awesome - think Bard's Tale songs. And they really cracked me up in Drogglejug mode.A few times some very loud sound pieces or music were played, e.g. when making "the discovery" coming back to the candy store. Also, Argus is too loud. I would have wished for those to be tuned down with the other volume settings.I really liked the interface, e.g. how the mousewheel seamlessly brings in and out the inventory. I think it an ingenious idea to have a shortcut to the save/load menu from the inventory and I applaud the employment of F-keys.The game logic is sound and puzzle threads are well graspable so that the player can follow the story without much stumbling.I really liked Drogglejug mode. It took me forever to get the reference even though multiple related hints appear throughout the game, e.g. the globe.Two more flaws:1. Sometimes the subtitles glitched from English to German.2. A major, almost off-putting, problem are the blocking black screens that happen when starting or quitting the game. With their three to five minute resolution time - all while catching any keyboard event, e.g. Alt+Tab, Ctrl+Alt+Del, Ctrl+Shift+Esc - I think a lot of people may have hard-reset their machines before realising the problem would resolve itself with time.I had the luxury of having another machine on my desk that I could use to search for the problem thus not experiencing the minutes as pure waiting time, otherwise I would have restarted machine 1 after less than 2 minutes. And I refrained from quitting the game in order to write this review without delay. So it's waiting time for me next.In case I didn't make it clear so far, I enjoyed Deponia :)I was looking forward to playing it and wasn't disappointed. And after my 3.5 play-throughs I'm looking forward to the sequel: Chaos on Deponia.Huzzah Drogglejug!

Posted: September 15, 2016
												Deponia brings the classic point and click animated adventure games to a new level of quality. A modern series of games with a system and artwork that might bring Leisure Suit Larry to mind, packed with a lot of humor and abstract situations. There's a plethora of characters with their unique personalities and tons of interesting stuff happening in the plot.It certainly is one of the best games in the point and click genre, yet it's not flawless. One of the flaws is that there are moments where you're clueless as of what you're supposed to do. You're stuck, trying to figure out what to do/where to use an object. After consulting with a solution, it turns out that the thing you didn't know was so ridiculous that you'd probably spend hours on trying to figure it out, and still not get it. + amazing humor+ very long+ original story+ interesting characters- many spots that are easy to get stuck at

I really enjoyed this part, is the more mature of the trilogy, while the second and third have somehow more childish quests. Great game!

Posted: July 12, 2015
												Deponia is a Point & Click game and the first part of a trilogy, preceding Chaos on Deponia and Goodbye Deponia.The game takes place on the planet Deponia, a real discharge on a large scale. At a distance floats a paradisiac platform, Elysium, reserved for rich people and inaccessible for the inhabitants of Deponia. We control Rufus, a clumsy character with an outsize ego, which loathes the household and working, and wishes only a thing: leave Deponia for Elysium. During an attempt to leave Deponia, Rufus meets Goal, a young inhabitant of Elysium who's here by mistake. He thus decides to return her at home, while hoping to be able to take advantage of it to join Elysium.All right, the scenario is not very original, we stay in the classic pattern of a prince who has to save the princess. But the universe is very nice, rather funny, both by the mind of the characters and by the nonsense of some situations. The gameplay is simple, we collect objects, then we combine them with other objects in the inventory to interact with the elements of the screen. Furthermore, by pressing on the space bar, we can locate at once the elements which we can interact, even if it is never very complicated to find them.Deponia is reminiscent of one of the pillars of the Point and Click, one of my favorite games: Monkey Island. Even if this latter remains much better, we do not remain indifferent to Deponia, to its cartoon animations, its colored universe, its musics and sound effects. Deponia should take you till 10 hours of game to end it. At the end of the game, you unlock the mode Droggeljug, completely useless, which replace all the names and conversations by the word "Droggeljug". But it's fun! :)

												It was an okay game. Some parts were difficult to get through as this game was sexist, homophobic, and transphobic. The main character is the "typical" egotistic, lazy, and dirty minded male. The plot is focus on Rufus attempting to leave Deponia, lugging around an unconscious damsel in distress, and then switching out her BRAIN IMPLANT for his benefit. Worst of all her name is GOAL! Really, that is her name!  Point and click adventures are a genre I enjoy, and it was sad to see such a difference in gaming experience between this and Edna & Harvey: Harvey's New Eyes. The puzzles themselves were enjoyable and there were moments of humor in good taste. Overall, I would not have bought this game knowing what it truly was, and ignored the very positive reviews. If you like a game that has sexism woven throughout, then this is a game you most likely will enjoy!

												Excellent adventure game -- a lot of humor.One interesting aspect of Deponia: You play Rufus, a protagonist whose character answers the question "How would a real-life person who grabs everything that is not nailed down behave?" You know the type [non-spoiler examples by the way]-- the one who insists that there is a perfectly viable reason to for example break into a museum at night to break a priceless ming vase because there might be something inside, and is sincerely apologetic he needed an amputee's prosthetic leg to knock a kite out of a tree instead of buying one from the store. One aspect: This is a game whose absurdity occasionally extends to puzzle design. So you will probably need either a walk-through or a large dose of experimentation to solve everything. Last comment: If you read the review and know you're going to love the game, go ahead and get the Complete Edition which bundles all three games. Just don't click on the commentary boxes until your second play-through.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												This game is amazing. The artwork is beautiful, the voice acting is great, the music is catchy, and the storyline is a tale to behold. As soon as I got it I started playing and couldn't stop. I managed to finish it in two days and am looking forward to getting the next in the trilogy. There are some spots that are a bit back-and-forth; but a double-click fast-travel really speeds things up. Some of the puzzles are a little hard to get a grasp of, mainly because they normally wouldn't work in real life; but this ain't reality folks. It's hard to find great games like this nowadays and I hope to find more. Good luck to all who play in the future.  d~(^.^)~bWARNING!I realize that some people have issues with some of the jokes being made, but try to remember that they are indeed jokes and aren't meant to offend. So anybody sensitive to that kind of comedy, stay away. And one more thing; the main character (Rufus) is understandably hard to like, but again, he is meant to be a sarcastic and satirical character, a joke.

												Would not recommend. The art style is fun, the mechanics and voice acting are fine. The puzzles are quite difficult at times, with not enough hints about what you're actually trying to achieve, so I spent hours walking around trying to combine every item with everything else (This is not the case for the most part, but a few sections were particularly frustrating). Fortunately the most difficult of the puzzles (the mini-games) are skippable. This would be not be an issue if the story and characters were engaging enough to draw you through the puzzles, but unfortunately none of the main characters are likeable, and the story is pretty thin. The humour is cute, but doesn't make up for the story and characters. I found the treatment of the female characters in particular pretty grating. There's supposed to be some self-awareness to it I think (the love interest is literally called 'Goal' after all), but she is comatose and generally treated as a possession for most of the game.

Posted: January 10, 2015
												Deponia is a great point-and-click adventure game. It has a fantastic art direction, interesting and well fleshed-out characters, a compelling storyline, and many hours worth of gameplay. It's a great series and you won't be disappointed.That being said, let's consider a few of the cons. Deponia suffers from the curse that haunts most point-and-click adventures: puzzle design. Progress in the game fan often consist not in figuring something out, but on clicking on everything, everyone, in every order imaginable. However, this is mostly a fault of the genre as a whole, true of even great masterpieces like Monkey Island, so you probably know if you can handle this kind of thing or not.Another con is the occasional villainous nature of the protagonist. While Rufus is certainly an anti-hero with plenty of personal faults that people will readily point out to him and which he will readily ignore, a few of his actions are simply mean-spirited. People being harmed by his carelessness is fun and good, but on more than one occassion he sets out to deliberately cause serious harms to his friends. This clashes with the rest of his character, and these moments really do stand out.The jokes can occasionally be crude as well. Nothing vulgar, and always humorous in my opinion, but I can also understand if others disapprove.And lastly, as spoiler free as I can say this, the end of the trilogy leaves several major loose ends.That all being said, Deponia was a fantastic experience and one I will readily share with my friends. The humor is clever, the dialogue is well written, the plot well constructed, and the game only improves as it goes on. Buy this game, support the developers, and demand a sequel trilogy, because this series deserves and demands one!

Posted: November 5, 2016
												Beautifully drawn, funny, with actually pretty good story (and world setting) masked by simple personal quest of an egocentric protagonist. But also Deponia is a time machine with a dial set to 90's which had twofold effect on me:First I remembered playing good old P&C adventures, warm and cosy feeling with occasional chuckle, and of course accompanied with frustrations because of illogical solutions and pixel hunting. But during those days we didn't have internet so you would be stuck on a certain puzzle for hours/days, repeating your steps making sure you didn't miss anything vital (did I mention illogical?) figuring out that you are dumb after all... Ahh *wipes the tear of reminiscence*Second thing is that I realized why this genre has died out. I can't imagine someone who grew up with today's games enjoying this kind of experience. Nothing here is on platter, you have to figure out on your own how to solve it. Or of course go and find a walk-through online, but they you would ask yourself are you enjoying this or even if is this is for you. So you would drop it and go play something in 3D with jumping and shooting with immediate satisfaction.If this came out in previous century it would be masterpiece worth remembering.

												I'd recommend it on a sale anyday.For the full price however, no.It's good, not perfect. The humor is cringeworthy at times, which I won't hold against them, since it's hard to make good humor at times. It does however have that "Saturday-morning cartoon" wich I like. It doesn't work in all games, but Deponia managed to pull it off more or less. I really like the visuals, makes me think of "The inner world", which also delivers the sam feeling. However, that games has a very uniqe and intresting setting, which this game fell short with sometimes. The story was something that took time before it got interesting, but in the end I was satified. Up until the ending however it felt like I was taking baby steps, and that I was making slow progress all the time. This could also have had to do with the fact that your goal was always the same.  What I have specifically in mind was the fact that you always have oyur focus on waking up Goal, fixing her brain implant and what not. It felt att times that she was not a character, but an object that I had to fix. Not until the end did this change, when she revealed her persenality and emotions towards your actions (like wanting to get to Elyssium). From what I've seen from the later games, thsi should change and she will have a bigger impact on the story.  The puzzels were alright, not to farfetched, which might happen to games that involves puzzels and humor.In conclusion, if you have some time over (I was between assignments at uni) and if you find it on sale, then give it a go.

												I like this game a lot.If you like games like Day of the Tentacle and Monkey Island, then you will probably like this game (and vice versa).If you prefer it when everything makes complete sense, then this is not a game for you.If you get this game and like me halfway through decide that you like it enough to also get Deponia : The Complete Journey, then don't do what I did and complete this game first. Posted: June 1, 2016
												Daedalic is probably one of the last companies making "traditional" point and click adventures around, as such, prepare for the sort of "logic" and comedy that usually is in titles like these. Deponia encompasses both the faults and the great things about the genre, wrapped around a funny story with some pretty good animation. Rufus, the main character, is very much a Guybrush Threepwood sort of deal. A not very capable person who somehow manages to worm his way out of a bunch of sticky situations with only a.. few.. bruises taken for it. This being the first of a trilogy that was already planned at the time, expect a lot of setup that hints at a deeper lore and character arc in the series beyond what we experience here. If you love point and click adventure, or just a good laugh, I recommend Deponia. Just remember, this is not an action title.

Posted: July 12, 2015
												Deponia is a Point & Click game and the first part of a trilogy, preceding Chaos on Deponia and Goodbye Deponia.The game takes place on the planet Deponia, a real discharge on a large scale. At a distance floats a paradisiac platform, Elysium, reserved for rich people and inaccessible for the inhabitants of Deponia. We control Rufus, a clumsy character with an outsize ego, which loathes the household and working, and wishes only a thing: leave Deponia for Elysium. During an attempt to leave Deponia, Rufus meets Goal, a young inhabitant of Elysium who's here by mistake. He thus decides to return her at home, while hoping to be able to take advantage of it to join Elysium.All right, the scenario is not very original, we stay in the classic pattern of a prince who has to save the princess. But the universe is very nice, rather funny, both by the mind of the characters and by the nonsense of some situations. The gameplay is simple, we collect objects, then we combine them with other objects in the inventory to interact with the elements of the screen. Furthermore, by pressing on the space bar, we can locate at once the elements which we can interact, even if it is never very complicated to find them.Deponia is reminiscent of one of the pillars of the Point and Click, one of my favorite games: Monkey Island. Even if this latter remains much better, we do not remain indifferent to Deponia, to its cartoon animations, its colored universe, its musics and sound effects. Deponia should take you till 10 hours of game to end it. At the end of the game, you unlock the mode Droggeljug, completely useless, which replace all the names and conversations by the word "Droggeljug". But it's fun! :)

												Easily my favourite point and click adventure game, and when I say 'adventure' I mean it, I have become so enthralled in the story and progression that I played it into the small hours of the morning without realising. Posted: October 25, 2016
												Droggeljug. Droggeljug. Droggeljug. Bought it on sale. It was fun, I enjoyed it. Gameplay is simple. Tip: You can double click to go to places faster. I didn't realize that sooner and I had to walk for the character to walk very very slowly. My fault though, not the game's. Anyway, it's an amusing point and click puzzle adventure game. Funny and ridiculous. Story is okay. Immediately bought the sequel (luckily it was also on sale) because I'm looking forward to what happens next!

Posted: October 22, 2016
												This was a fun point-and-click with enough challenging puzzles to keep me interested, but a bit lacklustre in other areas. I liked the premise - a world built on a junk yard - and I likedthat many of the puzzles required you to get creative and build things out of unconventional materials. I did get stuck a few times and had to look up prompts, which I hate doing, but it helped me think about future puzzles differently so I didn't need help towards the end. While the voice acting was decent enough, I found the characters to be quite generic, and I did not care for Rufus's weird creepy possessiveness of Goal as some kind of prize (even her name alludes to this). My main annoyance was that this game has way too much unnecessary dialogue; I put the subtitles on so I could quickly skip through the lines unless they had some useful information. The dialogue was often trying to be funny but much of it was fluff. I like this kind of Monkey Island style game with quirky humour, and there was some of that, but a lot of it could have been cut. The ending was a bit abrupt. I didn't really care for the storyline towards the end; it felt rushed and the puzzles became fewer and further between to make way for overindulgent cut scenes. Overall I enjoyed it, but I'm glad I got it at the sale price.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												Disclaimer: I have not played Deponia in English at all. This review is for the German version only.I can only say that this is a wonderful point-and-click adventure game. The makers very obviously love the genre, love writing, and love every single one of their characters (and they love singing, of course). The attention to detail, the backdrops, and even the "combine items in inventory" dialogue are all testament to this. The character animations and cutscenes are spot-on. Personally, I love the art style and the fresh humour most of all.Great place to start if you have never played a point-and-click adventure game before, too.

Posted: February 2
												This game, and the entire series (briefly but nolonger excluding 3) are all time favorites.  As dear to me as the classic Lucas Arts and Sierra adventures to which it is hommage.  The art, characters, and puzzles are enjoyable, with some very well executed fourth wall breaks (including a puzzle that must be solved from the options menu in 2 and a joke about the translation from german in 3). Well designed, well executed and a lot of fun.  When it's on sale under a couple dollars, I'll often buy a few copies to give to friends

Don't refrain from using a guide before you waste hours wandering cluelessly and eventually rage quittingCons:Puzzles are not always intuitive or logic at all;Lack of a clue system to avoid getting badly stuck;Idiotic drogglejug achievement;The constant humor gets old pretty fast;If you got this thinking it was a standalone game (as I did), too bad, you'll only see the true ending if you buy more 2 games (or more? idk);Some people will find the content sexist.Pros:Amazing art style, cool environments, decent voice acting.

Posted: February 25
												This game is solid.I've bought it at the time at a discount so it was defenately worth it for me.I don't know if paying a full price is actually worth it but it heavily depends on how much you loike the old style Sam&Max adventure games.I saw many reviews claim that sometimes the advencement was far fetched.As a old geezer who grew up on Day of the Tentacle, this game was actually quite easy.The humor is not a slap on your knee kinda of thing but more of a giggle.Not to say that it isn't well scripted and fun but don't expect to tear up.Overall, I enjoyed it and it made me purchase the full trilogy (and if I like them all I'll buy the 4th installment as well).

Posted: February 25
												Well.. it's a funny and nice point click adventure, with soe funny moments... But the annoying and childish Rufus is the good and the bad about this game. BTW, Rufus is the main character, just for you know. He is annoying, childish, selfish and really clumsy. He is also smart and creative, but not so much. This is the first of the 3 games of the trilogy Deponia, I reccommend you play all 3 to get all the story together. Because Rufus is annoying, but the game is not.
